USE - Recyclable and cross-linked nanocomposites in the form of shapeless mass, powder, sheets, prisms, cylinders, monoliths, sponges, aerogels, porous materials used in the manufacture of thermo-conductive materials, electro-conductors, converters of electricity into heat, filling composites, self-healing materials with electricity, self-healing materials with heat, self-assembling materials with electricity, self-assembling materials with heat, additive, binder (claimed).    DETAILED DESCRIPTION - An INDEPENDENT CLAIM is included for a method for preparing a nanocomposites that comprise derivatized polymer with pendant groups that act as dienes or dienophiles, and electrically conductive carbonaceous materials, which involves:    (A) functionalizing a polymer with pendant groups that act as diene or dienophilic, preferably the polymer selected from aliphatic polyketone, and the functionalization is carried out by Paal-Knorr reaction between the aliphatic polyketone and primary amines containing the diene groups or dienophilic including furfurylamine, being the molar ratio between the dicarbonyl groups of the aliphatic polyketone, where the primary amine allows conversion percentages between 1-100%, being then the molar proportion of diketone groups of the aliphatic polyketone and furfurylamine in the range of 1-100%;    (B) carrying out reaction at 50-200 degrees C in the absence of solvent, or alternatively using at least one solvent, which is selected from a saturated or unsaturated aliphatic or alicyclic hydrocarbon, an aromatic hydrocarbon, an alcohol preferably comprising at least 3C atoms, a glycol, a halogenated hydrocarbon, a ketone, ester, an ether or a glycol ether, or a mixture of two or more, preferably selected from tetrahydrofuran (THF), acetonitrile, N-methyl-2-pyrrolidone (NMP), dimethylformamide (DMF), 2-propanol, 1 propanol, toluene, benzene, chlorobenzene 1,2-dichlorobenzene, still preferably 1 propanol;    (C) carrying out additional derivatizations of the polyketones with organic side groups, including saturated and unsaturated alkyl groups, alcohols, amines, esters, ethers and polyethers, mercaptans under the same methodology in order to modulate the temperatures, glass transition, melting temperature or both below 200 degrees C in order to give the polymers the desired viscosity and fluidity;    (D) mixing the functionalized polymer obtained with a carbonaceous material selected from raw carbonaceous materials comprises electrically conductive carbonaceous materials including carbon, pitch, activated carbon, pyrolytic carbon, coke, graphite, combustion residues of organic material, or Electrically conductive carbonaceous materials selected from graphite, graphene, and carbon nanotubes, including single or multi-walled carbon nanotubes, fullerenes, or a combination of them or their derivatives, where the mixture is carried out at temperatures above the melting temperature of the polymer until the establishment of the retro-Diels Alder reaction in a preferential manner, including temperatures in the temperature range between 20-200 degrees C in the absence of solvent or alternatively in the presence of a solvent selected from water or organic solvents such as a saturated or unsaturated aliphatic or alicyclic hydrocarbon, an aromatic hydrocarbon, an alcohol preferably comprising at least 3 carbon atoms, a glycol, a halogenated hydrocarbon, a ketone, an ester , an ether or a glycol ether, or a mixture, where the proportion of derivatized polymer with pendant groups acting as furan functionalized diene or dienophilic (weight) and carbonaceous materials is in the range (10%:90-99.9%:0.1%) and the solvent volume in the range of 50-100%;    (E) mixing times vary between 10 minutes-1 week;    (F) adding additives, such as cross-linkers such as bis-maleimide, maleic anhydride, maleic imide, benzoquinone, alkyne, alkene, cellulose fibers, inorganic particles, metal salts, salts of lithium, copper salts, metal oxides such as titanium oxides, zinc oxide, copper oxide, metal nanoparticles such as gold and silver nanoparticles, metals, other polymeric materials, etc to manufacture advanced materials with various properties;    (G) separating the non-conductive residues from the raw carbonaceous materials by precipitation, centrifugation, filtration, or other conventional methods; and    (H) cooling the mixture, optionally grinding the nanocomposite, and storing, and optionally using it to give it another shape including compression molding, injection, supercritical fluid treatment, where the shapes include powder, prism, monolith, sheet, sponge, airgel. The weight of the coated fabric is 120-1500 gsm. The composite form can be stitched, welded (thermosealing), or hemmed to design a required shape of required size and geometry. The coated/laminated fabric can be stitched or welded or fixed with any kind of fixture to other materials like fabrics, plastic or metal sheets.    USE - For manufacturing protective cover, such as vehicle tarpaulins, agricultural covers, fumigation sheets, awnings, canopies, tents, and bio gas covers (all claimed).    ADVANTAGE - The method enables easy fabrication of protective covers having excellent mechanical strength, weather resistance, environmental resistance, dimensional stability, tear resistance, low-temperature flexibility, puncture resistance, and UV and thermal aging properties. The obtained protective cover is lightweight and easily recycled after use.    DETAILED DESCRIPTION - A protective cover is obtained by coating a thermoplastic olefin (TPO) compound lamina (1) on the side(s) of a polypropylene fabric (2) specifically by calendar coating. The weight of the coated fabric is 120-1500 gsm. The composite form can be stitched, welded (thermosealing), or hemmed to design a required shape of required size and geometry. The coated/laminated fabric can be stitched or welded or fixed with any kind of fixture to other materials like fabrics, plastic or metal sheets. The fabricated structure of coated fabric can be fixed with eyelets/grommet and ropes if required. INDEPENDENT CLAIMS are included for the following:    (1) use of fire/insect/microbe/UV resistant additive in TPO layer;    (2) use of woven, non-woven polypropylene fabric and blends made of yarns;    (3) use of ropes/loop or any material stitched, heat-sealed or fixed to the coated fabric;    (4) use of eyelets/grommets or fasteners of any metal/alloy or polymer to the fabricated structure; and    (5) recycling of coated fabric after use. A second                panel with second horizontal pattern comprising                cut-outs, where the second horizontal pattern                mirrors the first horizontal pattern. The first and                second panels are attached to each other via                through bolts. The panels are formed from                recyclable plastic pellets. The pellets have a                density of 0.94-0.965 g/cm3. The pellets are heated                together with a blend of mineral additives                comprising calcium carbonate. The first pattern                comprises two columns (13, 14) spaced approximately                0.96 inch apart.    USE - Recyclable polyethylene plastic man-door i.e.                standard swing door, for use in a building or                structure. Can also be used for pedestrian door,                pass door, access door and wicket, and providing                emergency exit.    ADVANTAGE - The man-door provides a convenient way to                enter a building or structure without having to                open a larger gate or overhead door. The addition                of mineral additives such as calcium carbonate to                high-density polyethylene will increase the                mechanical properties, such as plastic thermal                flexibility, strength, durability, and temperature                sensitivity, of the product. Unlike fiberglass, the                addition of polymer minerals and additives does not                negatively impact the recyclability of                polypropylene. The horizontal pattern                simultaneously strengthens the core of the man-                door, reduces the man door's ability to flex, and                reduces the weight of the door, and results in                zero-waste manufacturing operation. The man door is                made of a material that is sufficiently strong and                durable to withstand the wear and tear, so that                employees are not inhibited from quickly coming and                going through the door. The man-door has prolonged                service life, and reduces overall cost to the                consumer, and is recyclable, lightweight, strong                and durable.    DETAILED DESCRIPTION - An INDEPENDENT CLAIM is included for a method                for manufacturing a polyethylene plastic                door. Pref. mercaptan-based feedstream consists of mercaptan having 1-12 (1-8) C atoms per molecule. The oxygen-bearing feedstream consists of oxygen and an inert gas (pref. nitrogen), this feedstream is contacted countercurrently with the mercaptan-based feedstream, and the process further comprises recycling the depleted oxygen-bearing stream by combing the depleted oxygen-bearing stream with the oxygen-bearing feedstream.    USE/ADVANTAGE -   Disulphides are used in the mfr. of pesticides, rodent repellents, insecticides and in pharmaceutical synthesis, and also as additives in greases and diesel fuels. The process is safer and more environmentally friendly than prior art methods. 		   (JP6234731-A)      Disulphide prodn. comprises continuously reacting at least a mercaptan with O2 in the presence of a catalyst selected from alkaline earth metal oxide(s) and polystyrene-vinylbenzene copolymers.    USE -   Used for making pesticides and insecticides.    (JP2887037-B2)      The process comprises continuously reacting a mercaptan-based feedstream and an oxygen-bearing feedstream in the presence of a catalayst selected from: (a) alkaline earth metal oxides on a refractory metal oxide support; (b) alkaline earth metal oxides and alkali metal oxides in combination on a refractory metal oxide support; and (c) a polymer consisting of a basic form of macroreticular polystyrene-divinyl benzene copolymer, so producing a continuous disulphide product stream and depleted oxygen-bearing stream.    Pref. mercaptan-based feedstream consists of mercaptan having 1-12 (1-8) C atoms per molecule. The oxygen-bearing feedstream consists of oxygen and an inert gas (pref. nitrogen), this feedstream is contacted countercurrently with the mercaptan-based feedstream, and the process further comprises recycling the depleted oxygen-bearing stream by combing the depleted oxygen-bearing stream with the oxygen-bearing feedstream.    USE/ADVANTAGE -   Disulphides are used in the mfr. of pesticides, rodent repellents, insecticides and in pharmaceutical synthesis, and also as additives in greases and diesel fuels. The process is safer and more environmentally friendly than prior art methods. USE - A multi-fluid kit for three-dimensional printing a printed object (claimed), that is utilized in a commercial sector, such as aviation and medical industry.    ADVANTAGE - The antioxidant fluid agent reduces oxidation of polymeric build material used for three-dimensional printing. It reduces the effects of oxidative degradation that may be due to the relatively high stress environment that the materials of the three- dimensional printing kits are subjected during the additive manufacturing process. Oxidative degradation may lead to cosmetic issues, reduced mechanical properties, or the like. By applying these antioxidants to the 3D printed object using an antioxidant agent on a localized basis, negative impacts to the unused powder bed material that may otherwise be recycled can be minimized or reduced.    DETAILED DESCRIPTION - INDEPENDENT CLAIMS are included for:    (1) three-dimensional printing kit comprising powder bed material comprising polymer particles, fusing agent to selectively apply to the powder bed material, the fusing agent comprising water and electromagnetic radiation absorber, and antioxidant agent to selectively apply to the powder bed material, the antioxidant agent comprising liquid vehicle including water and 0.5-15 wt.% hindered phenolic antioxidant dispersed in the liquid vehicle; and    (2) making a three-dimensional printed object which involves iteratively applying individual build material layers of polymer particles to a powder bed, based on a three-dimensional object model, selectively applying a fusing agent onto the individual build material layers, based on the three-dimensional object model, selectively applying an antioxidant agent onto the individual build material layers, and exposing the powder bed to energy to selectively fuse the polymer particles in contact with the electromagnetic radiation absorber to form a fused polymer matrix at individual build material layers.  KANG H M;  KIM K S;  KIM Y S;  EUN J H	HYOSUNG CHEM CORP (HYOS-C)	202015125P	   NOVELTY - Preparing acrylic resin film involves                selecting alcohol-based solvents containing ethyl                alcohol as an auxiliary solvent from methyl                chloride, chloroform and methyl alcohol. The ratio                of the main solvent and the auxiliary solvent is                60/40 to 100/0 weight ratio. The core shell rubber                particles are dispersed under a solvent to prepare                a solution. The polymer comprises methyl                methacrylate (MMA) in the solution or methyl                methacrylate (MMA), phenylmaleimide (PMI),                cyclohexyl maleimide (CHMI), methyl acrylate (MA),                butyl acrylate, butyl methacrylate, alpha methyl                styrene (AMS), poly carbonate (PC), methacrylic                acid (MAA) and butyl acrylic acid (BAA). Butyl                acrylic acid dope is prepared by adding an acrylic                resin composition and a ultraviolet absorber,                silica, and other additives are mixed with each of                the polymer acrylic resin and the low molecular                acrylic resin composed of copolymer monomers. When                the residual solvent is 10 to 60 wt.% at 10 to 30                degrees C, 5 to 35% RH, peeled-off.    USE - Method for preparing acrylic resin film.    ADVANTAGE - The method enables to prepare acrylic film                that has improved modulus while securing a dope                viscosity and ejection processability by mixing a                low molecular acrylic resin with a polymer acrylic                resin. The method is eco-friendly and provides                thinning, mass production, and recycling of resins                when manufactured by the solvent casting method.                The optimized particle is added to increase the                impact strength and to secure the slip property for                film transfer. The acrylic film has excellent                transparency and coating adhesion compared to the                melt extruded acrylic film.    DETAILED DESCRIPTION - Preparing acrylic resin film involves                selecting alcohol-based solvents containing ethyl                alcohol as an auxiliary solvent from methyl                chloride, chloroform and methyl alcohol. The ratio                of the main solvent and the auxiliary solvent is                60/40 to 100/0 weight ratio. The core shell rubber                particles are dispersed under a solvent to prepare                a solution. The polymer comprises methyl                methacrylate (MMA) in the solution or methyl                methacrylate (MMA), phenylmaleimide (PMI),                cyclohexyl maleimide (CHMI), methyl acrylate (MA),                butyl acrylate, butyl methacrylate, alpha methyl                styrene (AMS), poly carbonate (PC), methacrylic                acid (MAA) and butyl acrylic acid (BAA). Butyl                acrylic acid dope is prepared by adding an acrylic                resin composition and a ultraviolet absorber,                silica, and other additives are mixed with each of                the polymer acrylic resin and the low molecular                acrylic resin composed of copolymer monomers. When                the residual solvent is 10 to 60 wt.% at 10 to 30                degrees C, 5 to 35% RH, peeled-off. The 100 to 250%                elongation at room temperature to 70 degrees C, MD                lead to 10 to 60 wt.% of residual solvent at the                time of stretching. The preheating is performed at                room temperature to 100 degrees C, stretching at 70                to 150 degrees C, relaxation at 100 to 200 degrees                C, elongation at 100 to 250%, and TD stretching is                performed at 50% or less. The drying is performed                at room temperature to 150 degrees C, and heat                treatment is performed at room temperature to 70                degrees C. The film winding comprising a tension                level of 60 to 300 Newton/1800 mm, where the                acrylic resin composition has a molecular weight of                500000 to 1000000 g/mole of 60 to 95 pts. wt.                polymer acrylic resin and a molecular weight of                10000 to 100000 g/mole of 5 to 40 pts. wt. low                molecular acrylic resin. (including polycarbonates, polyesteramides); alkyds; other unsaturated polymers.);  A32 (Polymer fabrication - such as moulding, extrusion, forming, laminating, spinning.);  A94 (Semi-finished materials - fibres, films, foams.)	A04-C05;  A04-D08;  A04-F04;  A04-F06C;  A05-E06;  A07-A04D;  A08-A03;  A08-M10;  A08-R06A;  A08-S02;  A11-B02A;  A11-B04C;  A11-C06;  A12-S06A;  A12-S06B	B29C-041/00;  B29C-041/24;  B29C-055/04;  C08F-120/18;  C08F-220/18;  C08F-279/00;  C08K-003/36;  C08L-033/12;  C08L-051/04	KR2020016437-A   17 Feb 2020   B29C-041/00   202019Pages: 11   ;  KR2203426-B1   18 Jan 2021   B29C-041/00   202107   	KR2020016437-A    KR091544    07 Aug 2018;   KR2203426-B1    KR091544    07 Aug 2018		KR091544    07 Aug 2018					129411-0-0-0 ; 368-0-0-0 ; 107016-0-0-0 ; 6-0-0-0 ; 20-0-0-0 ; 15-0-0-0 ; 7200-0-0-0 ; 404-0-0-0 ; 1622-0-0-0 ; 10151-0-0-0 			R00806 ; R00708 ; R01694 ; R00245 ; R00273 ; R00270 ; R00479 ; R00642 ; R00673 ; R00460 		WO9815518-A2;  AU9748936-A;  EP932593-A2;  BR9712228-A;  JP2001506585-W;  IL119389-A;  EP932593-B1;  DE69712215-E;  ES2175368-T3;  CA2267419-C;  US7238837-B1;  WO9815518-A3	Recovery of lactic acid from its aqueous salt solutions - by contact with insoluble cation exchanger to form free acid, for recovery, and reacting exchanger to recover cation to recycle	EYAL A M;  ELANKOVAN P;  ELANKO-VAN P	CARGILL INC (CRGI-C);  CARGILL INC (CRGI-C);  CARGILL INC (CRGI-C);  EYAL A M (EYAL-Individual);  ELANKOVAN P (ELAN-Individual)	1998286427	      Recovery of lactic acid (LA) from aqueous solutions, containing water soluble LA salt or salts, and having a pH of 4-14, comprises: (a) contacting the aqueous solution with a cation exchanger, at least partly in the acid form, to transfer protons from the exchanger and acidify the solution to form LA, with cations from the solution bound by the exchanger; (c) reacting the exchanger to regenerate it at least partly to its acid form, and a basic product, containing the cation, and (c) recovering the LA from the aqueous phase by known methods.    LA recovery is by contacting the acid solution with an extractant or adsorbent. These include liquid and solid anion exchangers, respectively. Recovery can also be effected by distillation, notably of LA ester. Regeneration of the cation exchanger in (b) is by hydrolysis; possibly at temperatures &gt;80 C. For volatile bases as is ammonia, this is transferred to the vapour phase. A second method is to conduct step (b) in a CO2-containing atmosphere. The cation exchanger has a pKa 2. The anion exchanger is a weak base, with pKa 6 (preferably 4.5). Operation can be either that the cation exchanger in partially acid form and anion exchanger in free base form are contacted simultaneously with the lactate salt solution.    USE -   LA has been used for a long time in various chemical and pharmaceutical applications, and as a food additive. More recently, LA has been used in manufacture of biodegradable polymers.    ADVANTAGE -   The process provides an efficient and environmentally friendly production of LA, avoiding consumption of acids and bases, and reduces or eliminates formation of waste and/or by-product salt streams. The CO2 mentioned above is used when the cation is calcium, precipitating calcium carbonate to force the equilibrium to LA. LA production is normally by fermentation; as the medium becomes acidic, a neutralising agent is required. Both ammonia, and calcium ion (the latter after conversion to hydroxide) can be recycled to the fermenter for reuse.  PATENT ABSTRACTS OF JAPAN vol. 13, no. 302 (C - 616) 12 July 1989 (1989-07-12),relevantClaims[1,3-6,29,31],relevantPassages[&lt;pp&gt;A&lt;/pp&gt;]	100000-0-0-0 P; 130151-0-0-0 P; 130510-0-0-0 P; 131587-0-0-0 P; 131724-0-0-0 P; 132059-0-0-0 P; 132237-0-0-0 P; 132461-1-0-0 P; 7447-4-1-0 P; 99-0-6-0 P; 134219-0-0-0 P; 94575-0-1-0 P; 7447-0-0-0 P; 99083-0-0-0 P; 99084-0-0-0 P; 3-0-0-0 			R00009 P; R01740 	0009-P	CN110744744-A	Producing plastic granule comprises preparing,            sorting and cleaning the recovered masterbatch, the            masterbatch is dehydrated first and then dried to            improve the drying efficiency, and masterbatch is put            into the shattering device	CHEN C;  ZHANG Z	NINGBO WANLONG MOULDING & PLASTICS FORMI (NING-Non-standard)	202011735V	   NOVELTY - Producing plastic granule comprises preparing,                sorting and cleaning the recovered masterbatch. The                masterbatch is dehydrated first and then dried to                improve the drying efficiency. Then the masterbatch                is put into the shattering device to shred the                masterbatch. The polymer resin must be sieved                before use. The powdery additives with coarse                particles or easy agglomeration are first refined                with plasticizers. The raw material should first be                estimated according to the equipment volume and the                feeding coefficient, and accurately weighed                according to the feeding amount. The weighing must                be accurate, otherwise the quality of the product                will be unstable. The good raw materials is added                to the high-speed kneader for mixing and kneading.                A twin-screw extruder is used to process the                plastic pellets.    USE - Method for producing plastic granule.    ADVANTAGE - The method enables to producing plastic                granule, which uses waste plastic products that are                recycled, which is beneficial to environmental                protection and reduces the production cost of                plastic particles, for reducing the use cost of                plastic particles and solving the existing plastic                problems. The most of the particles are made of new                high-pressure polyethylene, which leads to high                manufacturing costs, unfavorable environmental                protection and high use costs. 			A35 (Other processing and general - including vulcanisation, welding of plastics and adhesive processes. Testing.)	A11-A03A;  A11-A04;  A11-C03A;  A12-S09A	B29B-017/00;  B29B-017/04;  B29B-009/06	CN110744744-A   04 Feb 2020   B29B-009/06   202017Pages: 7   Chinese	CN110744744-A    CN11028297    28 Oct 2019		CN11028297    28 Oct 2019			CN110744744-A -- CN104044222-A   KUNSHAN BAOTENG PLASTIC MATERIAL TECHNOL (KUNS-Non-standard)   LAI Z;  CN104290214-A   TIANJIN XINTAINUO POLYMER TECHNOLOGY CO (TIAN-Non-standard)   SUN J		1013-0-0-0 			R00326 		US2003229168-A1;  WO2003104348-A1;  AU2003209159-A1;  EP1511820-A1;  US6890982-B2;  EP2083058-A1;  EP1511820-B1;  DE60328781-E;  EP2083058-B1	Hot melt adhesive composition for bonding fibrous            cellulosic article to other articles, comprises            thermoplastic polymer resin, tackifier resin, vegetable            derived wax, and composition has preset melting            point	BORSINGER G;  HASSAN A	BORSINGER G (BORS-Individual);  HASSAN A (HASS-Individual);  MARCUS OIL & CHEM CORP (HRDH-C);  MARCUS OIL & CHEM CORP (HRDH-C);  MARCUS OIL & CHEM CORP (HRDH-C)	2004081090	   NOVELTY - Hot-melt adhesive composition comprises (wt.%)                thermoplastic polymer resin (25-35), having vinyl                acetate content of more than 18% and melt viscosity                of 100000-600000 at 302degreesF, tackifier resin                (50-40) having acid number of 3-100, and vegetable                derived wax (15-35) having melt viscosity of 50-70                SUS at 200degreesF and Mettler drop point at                130-170degreesF. The adhesive composition has                melting point of 50-80degreesC.    USE - For bonding cellulosic articles, plastic, wood                and metal materials (claimed). Also used for carpet                seam sealing tape, lamination, product assembly,                non-woven construction, potting and encapsulation                compound, in manufacture of corrugated cartons used                for shipping refrigerated or frozen foods or for                shipping foods packed in ice, bookbinding, sealing                the ends of paper packs, furniture manufacture, and                adhering paper labels to plastic containers. The                wax composition is used as additive in the                manufacture of wax coated boxes.    ADVANTAGE - The hot-melt adhesive is safe and easy to use                since the wax contained in the adhesive composition                has melting point lower than the melting point of                wax traditionally used in hot melt adhesives. The                hot-melt adhesives are regarded safe for food and                drug administration. The composition is derived                from the renewable resource and is economically                produced compared to non-renewable petroleum based                compositions. The wax coated boxes are recycled                more easily than boxes prepared using conventional                waxes. The hot melt adhesives have an ability to                maintain a strong bond under difficult conditions                such as stress and shock in handling, and high                humidity and variations in environmental                temperature.    DETAILED DESCRIPTION - A hot-melt adhesive composition comprises (in                wt.%) thermoplastic polymer resin (25-35) selected                from ethylene or ethylene vinyl acetate, and their                copolymers or terpolymers, having vinyl acetate                content of greater than 18% and melt viscosity of                100000-600000 at 302degreesF, tackifier resin                (50-40) having acid number of 3-100, and vegetable                derived wax (15-35) having melt viscosity of 50-70                SUS at 200 degrees F and Mettler drop point at                130-170 degrees F. The adhesive composition has                differential scanning calorimetric melting point at                50-80 degrees C, and is capable of binding fibrous                cellulosic article to article chosen from fibrous                cellulosic article, wood, metal, glass and                plastic.    INDEPENDENT CLAIMS are included for the                following:    (1) wax composition essentially consisting of                vegetable derived wax and triglyceride having                melting point greater than 120 degrees F and iodine                value of 0-30, and comprising an oil selected from                soybean, corn, cottonseed, rape, canola, sunflower,                palm, palm kernel, coconut, cranbe, linseed and                peanut;    (2) cellulosic article formed using hot melt                adhesive composition; and    (3) composition for application to an article                intended to be bonded to another article. The filter material contains micropockets (4).    USE - A multilayer filter material comprising melt-blown fleece adhered to carded fleece of varied density. It is used in an air conditioning plant (claimed) or pleated filter (claimed). It filters particles from fluids, especially gases.    ADVANTAGE - The filter material is of uniform composition, simplifying recycling. Use of a separate adhesive is avoided. The layers are secured against movement. The material is manufactured and handled efficiently, without processing difficulties, including during the pleating process. Good mechanical stability is shown in use. Adequate air permeability and effective filtration are achieved in concert. The high dust storage capacity assures long life. This is enhanced by the presence of internal pockets.    DETAILED DESCRIPTION - The carded fleece staple fiber fineness is 0.9 - 12.0 dtex and its weight is 20-100 g/m2. Its thickness is 0.2-1.5 mm. A hot-pressing roller forms the compressed regions (8) and uncompressed regions (7). A structured drum causes thermofusion to this end. A structured drum introduces the regions hydrodynamically. Air-permeability of the carded fleece is 1500-6000 l/m2 x sec. The fibers include an antimicrobial additive. The melt-blown fleece thickness is 0.4-2.5 mm and its weight is 50-120 g/m2. Its air permeability is 300-1200 l/m2 x sec. An antimicrobial additive is included. The material of both fleeces comprises the same polymer.  EP910454-A1   IREMA-FILTER GMBH (IREM-Non-standard);  US4366054-A   KRONSBEIN D G (KRON-Individual);  US5445768-A   FREUDENBERG FA CARL (FREU)   DIETRICH B,  JOSEFIAK C,  FREUDENBERG U,  BARTH P,  HAUBER M;  US5486410-A   HOECHST CELANESE CORP (FARH)   GROEGER H G,  SERAD G A,  FELTON C D;  US6706086-B2   FIBERMARK GESSNER GMBH & CO (FIBE-Non-standard)   EMIG D,  RAABE E,  KLIMMEK A;  WO1998052672-A1   							WO2006104323-A1;  KR607704-B1;  EP1866140-A1;  CN101151139-A;  US2008190559-A1;  JP2008534731-W;  ZA200708325-A;  IN200703672-P2;  CN100544941-C;  US7679072-B2;  EP1866140-B1;  DE602006016925-E;  JP4837028-B2;  EP1866140-A4	Surface treatment apparatus for molded polymer product e.g. mobile casing comprises jig that holds product and feeds it sequentially through loading and discharging, impurity removing, vacuum and product surface ion treatment units	LIM D G;  LIM D	LIM D G (LIMD-Individual);  LIM D G (LIMD-Individual);  LIM D (LIMD-Individual);  LIM D G (LIMD-Individual)	2006789451	   NOVELTY - A surface treatment apparatus comprises a product feeding unit (10) having a jig (11) that changeably holds a molded polymer product and sequentially feeds the product through processing units including a product loading and discharging unit (20); a first impurity removing unit (30); an inlet vacuum unit (40); a product surface ion treatment unit (50); an atmospheric gas supply unit (60); an outlet vacuum unit (70); and a second impurity removing unit (80) of the apparatus.    USE - For treating the surfaces of molded polymer products (claimed), such as casings of electronic appliances such as mobile phones, personal digital assistants (PDAs), notebook computers, liquid crystal display televisions (LCD TVs), portable wireless transceivers, CD players, and MP3 players.    ADVANTAGE - The surface treatment apparatus for molded polymer products treats the surface of molded polymer product using a plasma ion beam scanning technique, thus efficiently shielding electromagnetic waves emitted from the molded electronic products and allowing the molded polymer products to be manufactured in large quantities. The surface treatment apparatus provides desired electric conductivity to the surfaces of the molded polymer products without using separate additives or fillers, thus reducing the production cost of the molded polymer products, simplifying the process of producing the products and allowing the products to be efficiently and easily recycled, thereby reducing environmental contamination and preventing waste of natural resources caused by the products. The surface treatment apparatus increases the effect of shielding electromagnetic waves and operational safety and reliability of the internal circuit units of the molded polymer products, remarkably increases the hardness of the outer surface of the molded polymer products, and accomplishes fineness of the products through surface reforming, thus increasing the durability of the products. Therefore, the apparatus remarkably increases the economic efficiency and operational performance of the molded polymer products and allows the products to be efficiently and easily recycled, so that molded polymer products capable of shielding electromagnetic waves can be easily produced in large quantities.    DETAILED DESCRIPTION - A surface treatment apparatus comprises a product feeding unit (10) having a jig (11) that changeably holds a molded polymer product and sequentially feeds the product through processing units of the apparatus; a product loading and discharging unit (20); a first impurity removing unit (30) placed at a side of the product loading and discharging unit for removing impurities from the surface of the molded polymer product; an inlet vacuum unit (40) placed at a side of the first impurity removing unit and having an interior maintained at a predetermined degree of vacuum; a product surface ion treatment unit (50) placed at a side of the inlet vacuum unit and having an interior maintained at a predetermined degree of vacuum, with an ion gun (51) provided in the ion treatment unit to scan ion beams onto a surface of the molded polymer product held and fed by the jig of the product feeding unit in the ion treatment unit; an atmospheric gas supply unit (60) connected to the product surface ion treatment unit and supplying atmospheric gas to the product surface ion treatment unit; an outlet vacuum unit (70) placed at a side of the product surface ion treatment unit, and having an interior maintained at a pre-determined degree of vacuum; and a second impurity removing unit (80) placed between the outlet vacuum unit and the product loading and discharging unit and preventing impurities from sticking on the surface of the molded polymer product fed from the outlet vacuum unit, and removing impurities from the surface of the molded polymer product. The inlet vacuum unit comprises an inlet having openable gates (90) at their opposite ends so that the molded polymer product held by the jig of the product feeding unit asses through the interior of the inlet vacuum unit. The outlet vacuum unit comprises an inlet and an outlet having respective openable gates at their opposite ends so that the molded polymer product held by the jig of the product feeding unit passes through the interior of the outlet vacuum unit.  AU9222050-A;  BR9203458-A;  CA2077123-A;  TW208034-A;  US5268438-A;  JP6041376-A;  US5310799-A;  NZ244174-A;  AU662914-B;  EP531093-B1;  DE69207309-E;  ES2083097-T3;  KR227918-B1;  JP3237913-B2	New copolymer, comprising vinyl! aromatic and (meth)acrylate! units - used to improve thermoplastic processing and moulding properties of aromatic polyester(s) for mfg. e.g. bottles, films, foams and pipes, etc.	CARSON W G;  LAI G;  MEMON N A;  LAI C;  MEMOM N A;  LAI C H	ROHM & HAAS CO (ROHM-C);  ROHM & HAAS CO (ROHM-C);  CARSON W G (CARS-Individual)	1993078592	      A copolymer comprising (A) 60-99 wt.% vinyl aromatic monomer units, (B) 1-40 wt.% hydroxy alkyl (meth)acrylate and/or epoxy alkyl (meth)acrylate units, and (C) 0-25 wt.% alkyl (meth)acrylate units, have a mol. wt. of 1,000,000-4,000,000.    Also claimed is a blend comprising (a) aromatic (co)polyester, and (b) the copolymer in a wt. ratio (a)/(b) of 99/1-70/30, opt. contg. 1-40 wt.% one or more other additives.    Pref. (A) is styrene, p-methylstyrene, chlorostyrene, vinyltoluene, dibromostyrene, tribromostyrene or vinylnapthalene. (B) is hydroxy ethyl (meth)acrylate, hydroxy propyl (meth)acrylate or glycidyl (meth)acrylate. (C) is a 1-4C alkyl (meth)acrylate. The polymer has a refractive index of 1.550-1.58. In partic. the polymer comprises 60-99 wt.% styrene units and 1-40 wt.% hydroxy ethyl methacrylate or hydroxy propyl methacrylate units.    USE/ADVANTAGE -   Small amts. of the copolymer improve thermoplastic processing and moulding properties of aromatic polyesters (claimed) by increasing their melt strength and melt viscosity. It disperses very readily in aromatic polyesters, yielding clear amorphous articles, e.g. bottles, films, foams, pipes, tubing, sheet and profiles. Addn. of the copolymer does not adversely affect recycling polyester 		   (US5268438-A)      Copolymer comprises (A) 60-90 wt.% vinyl aromatic monomer, (B) 1-40 wt.% hydroxy alkyl(meth)acrylate or epoxy alkyl(meth)acrylate, and (C) 0-25 wt.% alkyl(meth)acrylate. Copolymer has mol.wt. 1-4 million.    Pref. copolymer comprises 60-99 wt.% styrene and 1-40 wt.% hydroxy-ethyl methacrylate or hydroxy-propyl methacrylate. Pref. refractive index is 1.55-1.58.    USE -   Copolymers disperse readily in aromatic polyesters and are used to increase melt strength and melt viscosity of these.    (US5310799-A)      A blend consists of (A) an aromatic (co)polyester; (B) a copolymer of (a) 60-99 wt.% vinyl aromatic monomer, (b) 1.0-40, wt.% OH-alkyl or epoxy-alkyl (meth)acrylate and (c) 0-25 wt.% alkyl (meth)acrylate, the copolymer having a mol. wt. 1-4 x 10 power(6); and pref. also (C) 1-40 wt.% of at least 1 additive. The wt. ratio (A):(B) is 99:1 to 70:30.    (A) Pref. consists of a poly(alkylene terephthalate), esp. PET, poly(alkylene naphthalene dicarboxylate) or an aromatic copolyester esp. contg. units of an ethylene glycol, cyclohexane dimethanol or isophthalic acid.    USE/ADVANTAGE -   For prodn. of containers, bottles, foams and hollow parts by extrusion blow moulding. Amorphous, clear articles can be readily produced. The thermoplastic process and moulding of polymers is improved. 	A13 (Polymers of aromatic mono-olefins; including polystyrene.);  A23 (Polyamides; polyesters. Sell						WO2022084236-A1	Polyolefin composition used in e.g. packaging comprises polypropylene homopolymer, blend of recycled plastic material having polypropylene and polyethylene recovered by waste plastic material from post-consumer and/or post-industrial waste	KAHLEN S M;  LEGRAS A M D;  BRAUN H;  JERABEK M;  STOCKREITER W;  KASTNER E	BOREALIS AG (BORA-C)	202256347W	   NOVELTY - Polyolefin composition comprises: (a) 30-60 wt.% at least one polypropylene homopolymer; (b) 15-40 wt.% a blend (A1) of recycled plastic material comprising polypropylene and polyethylene in a ratio of 3:7-10:1, which is recovered from a waste plastic material derived from post-consumer and/or post-industrial waste having a melt flow rate 2 (MFR2) (230 degrees C, 2.16 kg, measured according to ISO 1133) of 8-14 g/10 minutes; (c) 17-50 wt.% glass fibers; and (d) 0.5-2.5 wt.% at least one coupling agent, and optionally further additives, where the sum of all ingredients add always up to 100 wt.%, where the polyolefin composition is characterized by: a melt flow rate MFR2 (230 degrees C, 2.16 kg, measured according to ISO 1133) of at least 2 g/10 minutes; a tensile modulus at 23 degrees C of at least 4 GPa (ISO 527-2); and an impact strength (ISO 179, charpy 1 eA+23 degrees C) of at least 5 kJ/m2.    USE - The composition is useful for manufacturing structural products, appliances, automotive articles, pipes, films, geomembranes, roofing applications, pond liners, packaging, caps and closures, as well as in core layer(s) of multilayer polyolefin sheet or film (claimed).    ADVANTAGE - The composition: utilizes virgin polymers, post-consumer recyclate (PCR) to make final solutions more economically friendly in regard to carbon dioxide footprint; utilizes polyolefin material recovered from waste plastic material with improved stiffness-impact strength balance; has melt flow rate MFR2 (230 degrees C, 2.16 kg, measured according to ISO 1133) of at least 2 g/10 minutes, tensile modulus (ISO 527-2) of at least 4 GPa, and an impact strength (ISO 179-1, Charpy 1eA +23 degrees C) of at least 6 kJ/m2; and employs in films (with thickness of less than or equal to 400 m) or for flexible foils (with a thickness of more than 400 m).    DETAILED DESCRIPTION - An INDEPENDENT CLAIM is also included for preparing the polyolefin composition, comprising providing a mixture of the at least first polypropylene homopolymer, optionally the at least one second polypropylene homopolymer, further optionally the at least one third polyproyplene homopolymer, even further optionally the at least one polypropylene heterophasic copolymer, where the blend (A1) of recycled material, glass fibers and the at least one coupling agent in the required amounts, melting the mixture in an extruder and optionally pelletizing the obtained polyolefin composition.  IN201817017440-A;  JP2019503945-W;  EP3360141-A4;  RU2018116590-A;  AU2016336036-B2;  AU2021204733-A1;  JP6915889-B2;  JP2021183516-A;  RU2761520-C2;  EP3360141-B1;  SG11201802885-B;  CN108292537-B;  ES2920838-T3	Composite panel for containing radioactive            materials for transportation or containment, has            reinforcing structure extending within            non-biodegradable thermoplastic polymer and integrally            formed with non-biodegradable thermoplastic            polymer	MOHARRER M A S;  MOHALLE M A S	HAZPROTECT PTY LTD (HAZP-Non-standard);  HAZPROTECT PTY LTD (HAZP-Non-standard);  HAZPROTECT PTY LTD (HAZP-Non-standard);  HAZPROTECT PTY LTD (HAZP-Non-standard)	2017254455	   NOVELTY - The panel (10) has a reinforcing structure                (12) extending within a non-biodegradable                thermoplastic polymer and integrally formed with                the thermoplastic polymer. The thermoplastic                polymer is mixed with an additive to increase                flexibility of the panel. The reinforcing structure                is encapsulated within an extent of the panel and                spans the extent of the panel. The reinforcing                structure is fixed within a matrix material (14)                which is a composition including the thermoplastic                polymer and a wax or fat. Engagement units are                coupled to the reinforcing structure and extend                externally of the panel.    USE - Composite panel for containing or                encapsulating radioactive materials and toxic                substances for transportation or containment, and                for a toxic material encapsulation system and for                use with a transportation system (claimed) for                various applications. Uses include but are not                limited to contain or encapsulate                radioactive/nuclear waste, medical waste from                hospitals, waste from energy production, mining or                manufacturing processes and low level radiating                waste for containing or encapsulating, and for                scientific research applications, industrial                applications, agricultural applications, medical                applications and production of                radiopharmaceuticals.    ADVANTAGE - The panel utilizes the transportation system                that shields radiation during transportation to                prevent accidental human exposure, and extracts the                toxic materials from waste to enable separation and                recycling of the material. The panel utilizes                radiation absorbing properties and longevity of the                non-biodegradable thermoplastic polymer, combined                with anti-leaching properties of the wax or fat                which improves formability/moldability of                composition, and a structural strength of the                reinforcing structure combine to provide the panel                with material performance and structural strength                for use in encapsulating toxic materials in a cost                effective manner. The panel utilizes an                encapsulation container to be shipped conveniently                as a flat pack without incurring large shipping                costs and quickly assembled on site. The panel                reduces an environmental impact of contaminated                water sources and removes toxic/hazardous                constituents for safe storage in a location. The                panel allows useful materials to be extracted from                the waste to reduce size of the waste so that the                waste is consolidated over time into smaller                containers to reduce a volume of material required                to be stored at a site.    DETAILED DESCRIPTION - The wax is selected from a group consisting of                paraffin, beeswax, Chinese wax, lanolin, shellac                wax, spermaceti, bayberry wax, candelilla wax,                carnauba wax, insect wax, castor wax, esparto wax,                Japan wax, jojoba oil, ouricury wax, rice bran wax,                soy wax, lotus wax, ceresin wax, montan wax,                ozocerite, peat waxes, microcrystalline wax,                petroleum jelly, fischer-tropsch waxes, substituted                amide waxes, cetyl palmitate, lauryl palmitate,                cetostearyl stearate, polyethylene wax, C3o-45                alkyl methicone and C3o-45 olefin. INDEPENDENT                CLAIMS are also included for the following:    (1) a container for encapsulating toxic                materials    (2) a method for encapsulating toxic                materials.    DESCRIPTION OF DRAWING(S) - The drawing shows a perspective cutaway view                of a panel.  US5225114-A   CHEM NUCLEAR SYSTEMS INC (CHNU-Non-standard)   ANDERSON R T,  PEARSON S D;  US5848111-A   ADVANCED CONTAINER INT INC (ADCO-Non-standard)   HOWE W F,  WELLS A H;  US20100176318-A1   ;  US20100284778-A1   ;  US7449131-B2   TRI-E SHIELDING TECHNOLOGIES LLC (TRIE-Non-standard)   HAYNER R E,  TERRY P R,  LOYD D D;  EP3360141-A4 -- US4021363-A   AEROJET GENERAL CORP (AERG)   STANDART M W,  SPARGO W E;  US4586624-A   BONDICO INC (BOND-Non-standard)   SHAW M D;  US5649323-A   COLOMBO P (COLO-Individual);  KALB P D (KALB-Individual)   KALB P D,  COLOMBO P;  US20110318441-A1   ;  US20140106635-A1   ;  CN108292537-B -- CN103106937-A   KEIWA SHOKO KK (KEIW)   NAGAMURA K,  KOBAYASHI H;  KR1527796-B1   RSMTECH (RSMT-Non-standard);  STS NETWORKS (STSN-Non-standard)   JEONG G W,  YANG Y J;  US4021363-A   AEROJET GENERAL CORP (AERG)   STANDART M W,  SPARGO W E;  US5225114-A   CHEM NUCLEAR SYSTEMS INC (CHNU-Non-standard)   ANDERSON R T,  PEARSON S D;  US5848111-A   ADVANCED CONTAINER INT INC (ADCO-Non-standard)   HOWE W F,  WELLS A H;  US20100176318-A1   ;  US20100284778-A1   ;  US7449131-B2   TRI-E SHIELDING TECHNOLOGIES LLC (TRIE-Non-standard)   HAYNER R E,  TERRY P R,  LOYD D D	EP3360141-A4            See also references of WO 2017059496A1	1013-0-0-0 ; 1145-0-0-0 ; 829-0-0-0 ; 368-0-0-0 ; 621-0-0-0 ; 129411-0-0-0 ; 192543-0-0-0 			R00326 ; R00964 ; R00835 ; R00708 ; R00338 ; R00806 ; R24072 		WO9815519-A2;  AU9748937-A;  EP932594-A2;  IL119388-A;  US6160173-A;  BR9712224-A;  EP932594-B1;  DE69714278-E;  ES2180952-T3;  CA2268311-C;  WO9815519-A3	Recovery of lactic acid from aqueous solutions as ester or amide - by contact with anion exchanger, then reacting directly with alcohol or amine without acidification	EYAL A M;  GRUBER P R;  MCWILLIAMS P;  WITZKE D R;  WITZKI D	CARGILL INC (CRGI-C);  CARGILL INC (CRGI-C);  CARGILL INC (CRGI-C)	1998286428	      Recovery of lactic acid (LA) values from an aqueous feed solution containing LA and/or its salt, comprises: (a) contacting the feed solution with an immiscible anion exchanger, to form a water immiscible phase, containing an anion exchanger LA adduct; (b) effecting a condensation between the carboxyl moiety of the LA in this phase with either a hydroxyl moiety, or with a primary or secondary amine moiety, to form a LA ester or amide product, and (c) separating the product from the anion exchanger. (The term 'lactic acid values' is defined as LA and its products, lactides, oligomers, polymers, or LA esters or amides).    Separation of the LA from the exchanger is by extraction into aqueous solution, into a solvent with low miscibility with the anion exchanger, or into the vapour phase. The LA feed solution from the fermentation has a pH of 4.5, and is as a sodium, calcium and/or ammonium lactate solution. Contact with the anion exchanger therefore liberates the cation; this is facilitated in a CO2 atmosphere, to liberate ammonia, or carbonates and bicarbonates of ammonia, or the alkali or alkaline earth metal. The anion exchanger is a moderately strong base, with a pKa 3.5 (preferably 4). The lactic acid/amine group mole ratio is &lt; 1. Condensation is carried out optionally in presence of a catalyst and at temperatures &gt;100 C at sub-atmospheric pressure, or in presence of a carrier gas, all 3 of which help to drive out water by product.    USE -   LA, normally produced by fermentation, has been used for a long time in various chemical and pharmaceutical applications, and as a food additive. More recently, LA has been used in manufacture of biodegradable polymers. In addition to LA, lactic acid esters, both with purity better than 99%, lactoyl lactate, and lactide can be obtained; the first has known uses as such, and all can be converted to LA by hydrolysis.    ADVANTAGE -   The process provides an efficient and environmentally friendly production of LA, avoiding consumption of acids and bases, and reduces or eliminates formation of waste and/or by-product salt streams. No evaporation of water is required, saving energy costs, as the process is carried out in a non-aqueous medium in which the solubility of water is small. On reaction to form an ester or amide, the LA loses its carboxyl function, and detaches easily from the anion exchanger. Alkanols, as by products from ester fission to LA can be recycled. 		   (EP932594-A2)      Recovery of lactic acid (LA) values from an aqueous feed solution containing LA and/or its salt, comprises: (a) contacting the feed solution with an immiscible anion exchanger, to form a water immiscible phase, containing an anion exchanger LA adduct; (b) effecting a condensation between the carboxyl moiety of the LA in this phase with either a hydroxyl moiety, or with a primary or secondary amine moiety, to form a LA ester or amide product, and (c) separating the product from the anion exchanger. (The term 'lactic acid values' is defined as LA and its products, lactides, oligomers, polymers, or LA esters or amides).    Separation of the LA from the exchanger is by extraction into aqueous solution, into a solvent with low miscibility with the anion exchanger, or into the vapour phase. Condensation is carried out optionally in presence of a catalyst and at temperatures &gt;100 C at sub-atmospheric pressure, or in presence of a carrier gas, all 3 of which help to drive out water by product. (US6160173-A)      Recovery of lactic acid (LA) values from an aqueous feed solution containing LA and/or its salt, comprises: (a) contacting the feed solution with an immiscible anion exchanger, to form a water immiscible phase, containing an anion exchanger LA adduct; (b) effecting a condensation between the carboxyl moiety of the LA in this phase with either a hydroxyl moiety, or with a primary or secondary amine moiety, to form a LA ester or amide product, and (c) separating the product from the anion exchanger. (The term 'lactic acid values' is defined as LA and its products, lactides, oligomers, polymers, or LA esters or amides).    Separation of the LA from the exchanger is by extraction into aqueous solution, into a solvent with low miscibility with the anion exchanger, or into the vapour phase. The LA feed solution from the fermentation has a pH of 4.5, and is as a sodium, calcium and/or ammonium lactate solution. Contact with the anion exchanger therefore liberates the cation; this is facilitated in a CO2 atmosphere, to liberate ammonia, or carbonates and bicarbonates of ammonia, or the alkali or alkaline earth metal. The anion exchanger is a moderately strong base, with a pKa 3.5 (preferably 4). The lactic acid/amine group mole ratio is &lt; 1. Condensation is carried out optionally in presence of a catalyst and at temperatures &gt;100 C at sub-atmospheric pressure, or in presence of a carrier gas, all 3 of which help to drive out water by product.  TSE M F;  GONG C;  JIANG P;  WAKABAYASHI H;  FU T M	BRANT P (BRAN-Individual);  TSE M F (TSEM-Individual);  GONG C (GONG-Individual);  JIANG P (JIAN-Individual);  WAKABAYASHI H (WAKA-Individual);  EXXONMOBIL CHEM PATENTS INC (ESSO-C);  EXXONMOBIL CHEM PATENTS INC (ESSO-C);  EXXONMOBIL CHEM PATENTS INC (ESSO-C);  EXXONMOBIL CHEM CO INC (ESSO-C)	2006170769	   NOVELTY - An amorphous syndiotactic rich polyolefin                comprises greater than 50 wt.% 3-40C alpha olefins,                and having 50-less than 80% r dyads, based on the                total number of r and m dyads present in the                polymer, a heat of fusion of less than or equal                to10 joules/g, and an ash content of less than or                equal to1 wt.%.    USE - The amorphous syndiotactic rich polyolefin is                for a polymer blend or a contact product, which is                heat stale. It is for use in an adhesive                composition useful for a consumer good, an article                of manufacture, a packaging adhesive, a package, a                disposable article, a film, a pressure sensitive                adhesive, a laminate article, a fiber product, a                hot melt adhesive, a carpet, a tape, a shingle, a                roofing element, a reflective article, a                woodworking article, a consumer article, a label, a                bookbinding article, a road-marking composition, a                sealant composition, a paving composition, a glue                stick, a pipe wrapping article, and/or an article                having a transparent pane (claimed). The adhesive                composition is useful for disposable diaper and                napkin chassis construction, and elastic attachment                in disposable goods converting. It is for use in                baby diaper leg elastic, diaper frontal tape,                diaper standing leg cuff, diaper chassis                construction, diaper core stabilization, diaper                liquid transfer layer, diaper outer cover                lamination, diaper elastic cuff lamination,                feminine napkin core stabilization, feminine napkin                adhesive strip, industrial filtration bonding,                industrial filter material lamination, filter mask                lamination, surgical gown lamination, surgical                drape lamination, and perishable products                packaging. It is useful for training pants,                sanitary napkins, panty liners, incontinent wear,                bed pads, surgical gowns, surgical drapes, rodent                traps, hook and loop fasteners, garments, medical                garments, and swimwear. It is may be applied to at                least a portion of disposable component(s)                including nonwoven fabrics, non-woven webs,                non-elastic nonwoven fabrics, elastic nonwoven                fabrics, necked-bonded laminates, stretch-bonded                laminates, spunbond-meltblown-spunbond laminates,                polypropylene spunbonded layers, polyethylene                layers, combination polyethylene and polypropylene                spunbonded layers, elastic strands,                styrene-isoprene-styrene,                styrene-butadiene-styrene,                styrene-ethylene/propylene-styrene,                styrene-co-butadiene-styrene, polyurethane, woven                fabrics, polypropylene, polyester, body fluid                impermeable back-sheets, body fluid impermeable                layers, body fluid permeable layers, body fluid                permeable covers, absorbents, tissues, elastomeric                materials, super absorbent polymers, polyolefin                films, polyester films, polyvinylchloride films,                polyvinylidine chloride films, polyvinyl acetate                films, elastic attachment tape, frontal tape                backing, wood, paper, barrier films, film                laminates, nonwoven composites, textile materials,                woven materials, durable fabrics, absorbents,                elastomeric strands, elastomeric webs, tissues,                films, coverstock materials, nonwoven polyethylene,                perforated polyethylene, super absorbent polymers,                filaments, porous webs, fibers, loop fastener                material, spunbonded nonwoven articles, liners,                elastic side panels, fastening tape, elastic bands,                rayon, nylon, cellulosic pulp, cellulosic fluff,                and super absorbent batts.    ADVANTAGE - The amorphous syndiotactic rich polyolefin is                soluble in various hydrocarbon solvents, at room                temperature, preferably having an ash content of                less than 1 w.%. It is of low crystallinity e.g.                (rrrr)less than 50%. The functionalized                syndiotactic rich polyolefins do not have a defined                melting temperature, and/or a heat of fusion of                less than 10 joules/g.    DETAILED DESCRIPTION - INDEPENDENT CLAIMS are also included                for:    (1) a polymer blend comprising an amorphous                syndiotactic rich polyolefin; and an additive(s)                comprising 2-40C polymer, 2-40C copolymer, an                elastomer, a random copolymer, an impact copolymer,                a functional polymer, a tackifier, a crosslinking                agent, an antioxidant, a neutralizing agent, a                nucleating agent, a filler, an adhesion promoter,                an oil, a plasticizer, a wax, an ester polymer, a                rubber toughened composition, a recycled polymer, a                block, an antiblock, a pigment, a dye, a processing                aid, a UV stabilizer, a lubricant, an adjuvant, a                surfactant, a color masterbatch, a flow improver, a                crystallization aid, a poly-alpha-olefin, and/or                group III basestock;    (2) a contact product comprising an amorphous                syndiotactic rich polyolefin, a functional group,                and a functionalization catalyst;    (3) a polymer comprising amorphous                syndiotactic rich polypropylene functionalized with                maleic anhydride, where functionalized                polypropylene comprises 50-less than 80% r dyads,                based on the total number of r and m dyads present                in the polymer; a heat of fusion of less than or                equal to10 joules/g; and an ash content of less                than or equal to1 wt.%;    (4) an adhesive composition comprising an                amorphous syndiotactic rich polyolefin, and/or an                amorphous syndiotactic rich polyolefin that has                been functionalized with a functional group, where                functional group, when present, comprises a                compound having a weight average molecular weight                of less than or equal to1000, and a carbon-carbon                double bond, a carbon-carbon triple bond, and/or a                heteroatom, the adhesive composition having a peel                strength to isotactic polypropylene of greater than                3.5 pounds/inches, and a peel strength to polyester                film of greater than 0.5 pound/inches;    (5) a process to make a polymeric material                comprising melt blending an amorphous syndiotactic                rich polyolefin and an additive(s) under high shear                conditions, to produce a concentrate containing                10-90 wt.% of the polyolefin, and subsequently                blending the concentrate with additional                material(s) to produce a final product; and    (6) a method to produce a functionalized                amorphous syndiotactic rich polyolefin comprising                providing an olefin monomer, metallocene catalyst,                and an activator to a reactor in an aliphatic                solvent; catalytic solution polymerization of the                olefin monomer in the reactor to produce an                amorphous syndiotactic rich polyolefin; monomer                stripping to remove unreacted olefin monomer;                solvent based functionalization comprising                combining the amorphous syndiotactic rich                polyolefin with a functional group, and with a free                radical initiator in the aliphatic solvent, at a                temperature and for a period to produce the                functionalized amorphous syndiotactic rich                polyolefin; and optionally removal of the aliphatic                solvent. R00902 	2038-U; 2044-U; 0610-S U; 1536-S U; 1950-S U; 0899-S U; 0474-S U; 0389-S U; 0476-S U	US2013184855-A1;  WO2013105974-A1;  US10026030-B2	System to identify information related to object comprises emitter to direct radiation to object, detector to receive radiation from diffraction grating on object, and processer to determine object information based upon radiation received	CHEN S;  ROTHFUSS C J	EMPIRE TECHNOLOGY DEV LLC (EMTD-C);  EMPIRE TECHNOLOGY DEV LLC (EMTD-C);  CHEN S (CHEN-Individual);  ROTHFUSS C J (ROTH-Individual)	2013L89988	   NOVELTY - A system for identifying information related to object (402) comprises: radiation emitter configured to direct radiation toward object (406); detector (408) configured to receive modified radiation (410) from diffraction grating on object; and processing device (412) operably connected to detector and configured to determine information related to object based upon modified radiation received at detector.    USE - As system for identifying information related to object, such as polymeric object, where information comprises at least one of material composition of object, melting temperature of object, composition type of object, and at least one additive added to object; for manufacturing object; and for sorting plastic objects to be recycled (all claimed). Also useful for additional products or goods such as currency, electronic devices, pharmaceuticals, medical devices, pharmaceutical packaging, artwork, computer readable media, glass containers, jewelry, memorabilia, automotive components, credit cards, certified documents, copyrighted works, paper goods, furniture, building materials, aeronautical components, textiles, and other similar goods or materials.    ADVANTAGE - The system and method for identifying information related to object provide passive, microscopic tagging or bar-coding of various commodities or products, such as plastics, at time of manufacture, or after manufacturing, for identification purposes. The tagging or bar-coding maintains optical properties of products, such as inherent transparency of some plastics, while encompassing low cost and highly selective and sensitive methods and systems for identifying products that are easily integrated into existing manufacturing processes. The microscopic tagging or bar-coding includes reflective and/or transmissive diffraction grating incorporated into product during or after manufacture, where diffraction grating operates when structure is on order of, or smaller than, wavelength of incident radiation. The grating is arranged such that grating responds to non-optical wavelengths such as infrared (IR), microwave radiation, long radio frequency (RF), or ultraviolet to sub-optical wavelengths. The wavelength response(s) of grating (e.g. frequency response cutoff, spectral bands) to broadband and/or monochromatic sources is exploited to encode information related to product tagged with grating. The grating is imprinted into product itself or molded, etched or imprinted on or in coating. Thus system and method provide improved product identification method than embedding forensic-like particles into plastics, chemically bar-coding plastics, or otherwise tagging plastics at time of manufactures; having cost and implementation challenges because of scale, increases in cost, difficult process integration, and other similar factors. Additionally, typical markings such as chemical bar-coding or embedding foreign particles alter original properties of plastic such as strength and transparency.    DETAILED DESCRIPTION - A system for identifying information related to object (402) comprises: radiation emitter configured to direct radiation toward object (406); detector (408) configured to receive modified radiation (410) from diffraction grating on object; and processing device (412) operably connected to detector and configured to determine information related to object based upon modified radiation received at detector. The diffraction grating is reflective diffraction grating. The diffraction grating comprises non-optical wavelength diffraction grating. The radiation emitter comprises infrared emitter and/or microwave emitter. The detector comprises infrared detector, infrared camera, monochronometer, spectrometer, microwave detection unit, antenna, and/or microwave filter. The system further comprises sorting device (414) configured to sort object based upon determination by processing device of information related to object. The object is formed by extruding quantity of polymer through at least one die to form object and/or filling mold with quantity of polymer to form object. INDEPENDENT CLAIMS are included for the following:    (1) method for identifying information related to object, involving: directing radiation from radiation emitter to object; receiving modified radiation directed by diffraction grating on object toward detector; and determining information related to object at processing device operably connected to detector, where information is based upon modified radiation received at detector;    (2) method for manufacturing object, involving: forming object; and applying at least one diffraction grating to object, where at least one diffraction grating defines information related to object; and    (3) method for sorting plastic objects to be recycled, involving: directing radiation from radiation emitter to plastic object; receiving modified radiation directed by diffraction grating on plastic object toward detector; determining information related to type of plastic used to manufacture plastic object at processing device operably connected to detector, where information is based upon modified radiation received at detector; and sorting plastic object at sorting device operably connected to processing device, where sorting is based upon type of plastic used to manufacture plastic object.    DESCRIPTION OF DRAWING(S) - The figures shows detection system for identifying information related to object.  WO200100399-A1;  AU200050785-A;  EP1198345-A1;  CZ200104546-A3	Composite useful in automobile manufacture and laminate production, with at least two molded parts and bonding regions and not subject to profile instability on heating	FISCHER M;  RAU W;  WELZ M	BASF AG (BADI-C);  BASF AG (BADI-C);  BASF AG (BADI-C);  BASF AG (BADI-C)	2001183925	   NOVELTY - A composite comprising at least a first and second molded part, which are strongly bonded together via a bonding region at least one part of a surface alpha of the first molded part and a surface beta of the second molded part is new.    USE - The composite is useful in motor vehicle construction (claimed) and for laminates.    ADVANTAGE - The composite avoids some of the drawbacks of previous composites, e.g. poor profile stability on heating, which is undesirable, especially for car interiors.    DETAILED DESCRIPTION - A composite comprising at least a first and second molded part, which are strongly bonded together via a bonding region at least one part of a surface alpha of the first molded part and a surface beta of the second molded part. At least the first molded part consists of at least 50 wt.% of a molding material relative to the sum of the percentage weights of components (A) to (I) containing (wt.%):    (A) at least one polycondensate (up to 97.9);    (B) at least one particle-shaped graft polymerisation in which the Tg of the soft phase is below 0degreesC, and the mean particle size is 50-1000 nm (1-12);    (C) at least one copolymerisable as component C (1-12) from the monomers:    (1) at least one vinyl aromatic monomer as component C1 (50-90) (relative to component C);and    (2) acrylonitrile; and/or methacrylonitrile as component C2 (10-50), (relative to component C);    (D) a polycarbonate (0-15);    (E) a rubber different from component B containing a polymer (0-15);    (F) a polyester different from component A (0-20);    (G) a copolymer different from C, at least from one of a 1-10C alkyl residue carrying vinyl aromatic monomer and with this polymerizable vinyl monomer (0-20);    (H) at least one fiber (1-10); and    (I) conventional additives such carbon black, UV stabilizer, oxidation retarder, lubricant and forming agent (0.1-10).    INDEPENDENT CLAIMS are included for:    (1) preparation of a formed part where at least surface alpha is bonded to surface beta forming a bonding region;    (2) a recycle of molded parts or molding material, or at least two of these; and    (3) a structure comprising at least a composite as above or at least two of these.  JIN H;  HUANG T	UNIV GUANGDONG TECHNOLOGY (UGTE-C)	2009S27134	   NOVELTY - A high-power high-energy iron phosphate lithium battery comprises anode, cathode, isolation film, electrolyte, and battery shell. The anode comprises anode current collector and anode material coated on its surface. The cathode comprises cathode current collector and cathode material coated on its surface. The anode material comprises iron phosphate lithium, anode conductive agent, metal oxide, and plastering agent. The cathode material comprises compound of cathode active substance native graphite and electro-graphite, cathode active substance, cathode conductive agent, and sizing agent.    USE - A high-power high-energy iron phosphate lithium battery.    ADVANTAGE - The battery has large capacity, good recycling property, high safe property, and high electrical conductivity. It is discharged or charged with large current and its method of manufacture has low cost and simple operation.    DETAILED DESCRIPTION - High-power high-energy iron phosphate lithium battery comprises anode, cathode, isolation film, electrolyte, and battery shell. The anode comprises anode current collector and anode material coated on its surface. The cathode comprises cathode current collector and cathode material coated on its surface. The anode material comprises iron phosphate lithium (87-94 wt.%), anode conductive agent (1-2 wt.%), metal oxide (2-9 wt.%), and plastering agent (3-5 wt.%). The cathode material comprises compound of cathode active substance native graphite and electro-graphite, cathode active substance (90-93 wt.%), cathode conductive agent (1-5 wt.), and sizing agent (2-9 wt.%). An INDEPENDENT CLAIM is included for a making method of the iron phosphate lithium battery comprising:    (A) using alkaline liquor to wash anode current collector, using acid liquor to wash cathode current collector, and blowing them dry;    (B) placing iron phosphate lithium powder, metal oxide, and anode conductive agent into N-methyl-ketopyrrolidine solution of the plastering agent, mixing uniformly to form polymer, and coating on the washed anode current collector;    (C) placing mixed powder of native graphite and artificial graphite, and cathode conductive agent into aqueous solution of sizing agent, mixing uniformly to form polymer, and coating on the washed cathode current collector;    (D) drying the anode and cathode, rolling with a roller, and cutting down and rolling to obtain anode and cathode pieces;    (E) processing lithium salt at high temperature, and dissolving into mixed solvent of organic solvent and additive to obtain electrolyte; and    (F) putting the anode and cathode pieces into the electrolyte, installing an isolation film between the anode and cathode pieces, and installing a battery shell to obtain the iron phosphate lithium battery.
