The                recycled polyethylene has: a density of 0.92-0.975                g/cm3 when measured according to ASTM D792-08,                Method B; a melt index of 0.3-3 dg/minute when                measured according to ASTM D1238-10, Method B, at                190 degrees C and 2.16 kg load; and a melt flow                ratio (MFR21) of greater than or equal to 50, where                the melt flow ratio is a ratio of a high load melt                index of the recycled polyethylene to the melt                index, and the high load melt index is measured                according to ASTM D1238-10, Method B, at 190                degrees C and 21.6 kg load.    USE - The composition is useful in manufactured                article and coated conductor (all claimed).    ADVANTAGE - The composition exhibits at least one of: an                average tensile strength at break greater than or                equal to 1400 psi when measured according to ASTM                D638-14, Type IV; an elongation at break greater                than or equal to 200% when measured according to                ASTM D638-14, Type IV; an environmental                stress-cracking resistance of greater than or equal                to 24 hours when measured according to ASTM                D1693-1, Method B, in 10% Igepal (RTM:                Octylphenoxy) solution at 50 degrees C; and a                secant modulus of greater than 450 MPa when                measured according to ASTM D790-17. The composition                has improves sustainability by increasing the                post-consumer recycled polymers included while also                maintaining suitable environmental stress-cracking                resistance and mechanical properties.    DETAILED DESCRIPTION - Thermoplastic composition comprises: 0.5-75                wt.% a recycled polyethylene comprising a blend of                polyethylene recovered from post-consumer material                and/or pre-consumer material; and 25-99.5 wt%                virgin raw polyethylene comprising unimodal                polyethylene and/or bimodal polyethylene. The                recycled polyethylene has: a density of 0.92-0.975                g/cm3 when measured according to ASTM D792-08,                Method B; a melt index of 0.3-3 dg/minute when                measured according to ASTM D1238-10, Method B, at                190 degrees C and 2.16 kg load; and a melt flow                ratio (MFR21) of greater than or equal to 50, where                the melt flow ratio is a ratio of a high load melt                index of the recycled polyethylene to the melt                index, and the high load melt index is measured                according to ASTM D1238-10, Method B, at 190                degrees C and 21.6 kg load. The unimodal                polyethylene has: a density of 0.93-0.95 g/cm3 when                measured according to ASTM D792-08, Method B; a                melt index of 0.3-1 dg/minute when measured                according to ASTM D1238-10, Method B, at 190                degrees C and 2.16 kg load; and melt flow ratio of                greater than or equal to 30, where the melt flow                ratio is a ratio of a high load melt index of the                unimodal polyethylene to the melt index, and the                high load melt index is measured according to ASTM                D1238-10, Method B, at 190 degrees C and 21.6 kg                load. The bimodal polyethylene has: a density of                0.933-0.96 g/cm3 when measured according to ASTM                D792-08, Method B; a melt index of 0.3-2 dg/minute                when measured according to ASTM D1238-10, Method B,                at 190 degrees C and 2.16 kg load; melt flow ratio                of greater than or equal to 80, where the melt flow                ratio is a ratio of a high load melt index of the                bimodal polyethylene to the melt index, and the                high load melt index is measured according to ASTM                D1238-10, Method B, at 190 degrees C and a 21.6 kg                load; a molecular weight distribution (Mw/Mn) of                greater than or equal to 6, where the molecular                weight distribution is a ratio of a weight average                molecular weight (Mw) of the bimodal polyethylene                to a number average molecular weight (Mn) of the                bimodal polyethylene, and the weight average                molecular weight (Mw) and the number average                molecular weight (Mn) are measured using gel                permeation chromatography (GPC); a reverse                comonomer distribution, where a ratio of a short                chain branching distribution of the high molecular                weight component (SCBD2) to a short chain branching                distribution of the low molecular weight component                (SCBD1) is greater than 1, and the short chain                branching distribution of the high molecular weight                component (SCBD2) and the short chain branching                distribution of the low molecular weight component                (SCBD1) are measured using GPC; and at least 90                wt.% the thermoplastic composition is comprised of                the recycled polyethylene and the virgin raw                polyethylene. INDEPENDENT CLAIMS are also included                for:    (1) making (M1) the thermoplastic composition,                comprising melt-blending the recycled polyethylene,                the virgin polyethylene, and any optional                additives, thus making the thermoplastic                composition;    (2) a manufactured article comprising the                thermoplastic composition;    (3) a coated conductor comprising a coating                layer and a conductive core, where the coating                layer comprises the thermoplastic composition and                covers at least a portion of the conductive core;                and    (4) transmitting (M2) electricity and/or light                through a conductive core of the coated conductor,                where the conductive core comprises a metallic wire                and/or an optical fiber, comprising (a) applying a                voltage across the metallic wire, thus causing                electrical energy to flow through the metallic                wire, and/or (b) sending a pulse of light (e.g.                infrared light) through the optical fiber, thus                causing light to transmit through the optical                fiber, and transmitting electricity and/or light,                respectively, through a conductive core of the                coated conductor. The system provides a hygienic unit of                cleaning the nose that will render nose picking a                thing of the past, replacing fingers with a                sanitary device that effectively cleans the nose. USE - In forming article (claimed) e.g. automotive interiors, wall coverings, upholstery, advertising banners and films, tenting, coated yarns and coated yarn fabrics, window treatment fabrics, and floor coverings, which are used aerospace applications, interior office applications, mining and interior residential applications where time of egress is an important element to occupants having the time to escape a burning building or room; and in juvenile care products like fabrics used in the constructions of juvenile bedding, cribs, blankets, clothing, seating, and play pins; as juvenile bedding and children's quick clean up fabrics, shower curtains; in commercial and private aircraft applications by themselves or formed into multilayered composite structures such as cargo bay liners, interior fuselage coverings, airplane interior upholstery and seating, trays, floor panels and underlayment and insulation blanket components.    ADVANTAGE - The composition polyolefin provides high levels of flame retardancy, ease of processing, lower extrusion and down stream conversion costs, little to no toxic off-gassing, low smoke density during combustion, excellent mechanical properties, desirable hand characteristics and flexibility, ease of printing, excellent adhesion to a variety of substrates, and overall economical raw material costs that can be extruded into cast and blown films, cast extruded directly onto substrates, cross head extruded to coat yarns, and formed into a fibers and other thin cross sections for use in end use applications such as automotive interiors, wall coverings, upholstery, advertising banners and films, tenting, coated yarns and coated yarn fabrics, window treatment fabrics, and floor coverings as replacement materials where flexible PVC is used in those same applications. The elastomeric polyolefin compositions and the resultant end use film, fiber, yarn, coated or laminated scrim or fabric onto which they are adhered must be able to pass standard industry or regulatory flame retardant, smoke density and toxic off-gassing tests with ease. The composition impart high levels of outdoor weathering performance, can be easily colored through the use of additive pigments common to the use of polyolefins, while providing ease of recycling and have no toxicity to the environment or living organisms.    DETAILED DESCRIPTION - An elastomeric polyolefin composition comprises: at least one flexible or elastomeric polyolefin polymer; sufficient amount of polypropylene homopolymer in a concentration to impart the composition to a final Shore A hardness of 50-96; brominated flame retardant; hypophosphorous acid metal salt of formula (PH2O2)nM1 (I); several additives selected from migratory surface modifiers (0-0.25 wt.%) which act as external lubricants, tertiary sterically hindered amine ultra violet light stabilizer(s) (0-2 wt.%), organic pigments and colorants and/or inorganic pigments and colorants; and optionally filler having a pH of less than 7. The elastomeric polyolefin composition has a density of less than 1 g/cm3 and Shore A hardness of 60-94 as measured according to ASTM D-2240. The final elastomeric composition can be extrusion processed using cast film extrusion, extrusion coating onto a substrate, cross head extrusion coating onto a monofilament or multifilament yarn, calendaring, or used in a blown film extrusion process.    M1=metal atom belonging to the groups I, II, III, or IV of the periodic table of the elements;    n=1-4 depending on the valence of the metal M1.    An INDEPENDENT CLAIM is included for an article of manufacture comprising the elastomeric polyolefin composition which has been formed into a film, where the film meets or exceeds the requirements of the flame retardant specifications as defined for textiles by the National Fire Protection Association Test 701, year editions 1989, 1999, 2004 and 2010; has been formed into an extrusion coated fabric or a calendared film which has been adhered onto a fabric, where the coated fabric meets or exceeds the requirements of the flame retardant specifications as defined for textiles by the National Fire Protection Association Test 701, year editions 1989, 1999, 2004 and 2010; has been formed into a laminated article comprising a film that is laminated onto a supportive scrim fabric or a calendared film adhered to a supportive scrim fabric, and the laminated article, extrusion coated fabric, calendared film adhered to a supportive scrim fabric, or laminated fabric meets or exceeds the requirements of the flame retardant specifications as defined for textiles by the National Fire Protection Association Test 701, year editions 1989, 1999, 2004 and 2010; has been formed into a film, where the film meets or exceeds the requirements of the flame retardant specifications as defined for textiles and related constructions by the California State Fire Marshal Title 19 California Code of Regulations; when coated onto a multifilament or monofilament textile or other yarn via an extrusion coating or cross head die extrusion process and the yarns are woven or in some other way formed into a usable fabric, such fabrics meet or exceed the requirements of the flame retardant specifications as defined for textiles by the National Fire Protection Association Test 701, year editions 1989, 1999, 2004 and 2010; which has been formed into an extrusion coated fabric or a calendared film which has been adhered onto a fabric, where the coated fabric meets or exceeds the requirements of the flame retardant specifications as defined for textiles and related constructions by the California State Fire Marshal Title 19 California Code of Regulations; or which has been formed into a laminated article comprising a film that is laminated onto a supportive scrim fabric or a calendared film adhered to a supportive scrim fabric, where the laminated article, extrusion coated fabric, or a calendared film adhered to a supportive scrim fabric, or laminated fabric meets or exceeds the requirements of the flame retardant specifications as defined for textiles and related constructions by the California State Fire Marshal Title 19 California Code of Regulations. 			A17 (Polymers of unsubstituted aliphatic monoolefins; including polyethylene.);  A14 (Polymers of other substituted monoolefins; including PVC, PTFE.);  A83 (Clothing, footwear.);  A93 (Roads, building, construction flooring.);  A95 (Transport - including vehicle parts, tyres and armaments.);  A97 (Miscellaneous goods not specified elsewhere - including papermaking, gramophone records, detergents, food and oil well applications.)	A04-G01C;  A04-G03C;  A07-A02D;  A08-F03;  A08-F04;  A11-B01;  A11-B09D	C08K-003/22;  C08K-003/32	US8394879-B1   12 Mar 2013   C08K-003/32   201321Pages: 19   English	US8394879-B1    US097034    28 Apr 2011	US8394879-B1 Provisional Application US329533P	US329533P    29 Apr 2010;  US097034    28 Apr 2011			US8394879-B1 -- US5891571-A   ALCAN INT LTD (ALCN)   HERBERT M J;  US20060270298-A1   ;  US20080214715-A1   ;  US20100324182-A1   ;  WO2009080554-A1   CIBA HOLDING INC (CIBA)   ROTH M		1145-0-0-0 			R00964 		WO2022043671-A1;  GB2598715-A;  GB2598715-B	Producing metal nanoparticle by providing            dissolved metal ion, and contacting with composition            comprising extracts from kale (Brassica oleracea            Acephala group), and at least one other plant e.g.            artichoke (Cyanara cardunculus), and oregano (Origanum            vulgare), rosemary (Salvia cormanus)	TROTTA F	METALCHEMY LTD (META-Non-standard)	202231440X	   NOVELTY - Method of producing a metal nanoparticle,                comprises: (a) providing a dissolved metal ion; and                (b) contacting the dissolved metal ion with a                composition comprising extracts from: (a) kale                (Brassica oleracea Acephala group); and (b) at                least one other plant chosen: (i) artichoke                (Cyanara cardunculus); (ii) red cabbage (Brassica                oleracea Capitata group var. rubra); (iii) oregano                (Origanum vulgare); (iv) rosemary (Salvia                cormanus); (v) sage (Salvia officinalis); (vi)                watercress (Nasturtium officinale); (vii) dog rose                (Rosa canina); (viii) mint (Mentha spp.); (ix)                thyme (Thymus spp.); (x) basil (Osimum basilicum)                and (xi) spinach (Spinacia oleracea), such that the                dissolved metal ion is reduced to form the metal                nanoparticle.    USE - The method is used for producing a metal                nanoparticle for a product (claimed) such as                cosmetic product, a battery, pharmaceutical product                (which may be an active pharmaceutical ingredient,                a pharmaceutical excipient or a drug delivery                agent), a plant protection product, such as an                agricultural chemical product (which may be an                active agrochemical ingredient, an agrochemical                excipient or an agrochemical delivery agent), a                construction material, a detergent or cleaning                product, a biological sensor, a lubricant, an optic                or optoelectronic device, a conductive ink, an                antimicrobial agent, a biocidal agent (including a                pesticide), a catalyst, an enhanced material (such                as a polymer, which may be a nanoparticle-embedded                polymers, or a functionalized material or                derivative), a preservative (such as a food                preservative), a filter (a filter for air and/or                water purification), and a machine (such as a                robot, which may be a nano-robot). The metal                nanoparticle is used in biomedical imaging, in gene                sequencing, in information storage and processing                (including nanocomputing and quantum computing                applications), and in nanoelectronics, and is used                for producing a textile product or article of                clothing, an article of footwear, or an accessory                (such as a jewellery item, a bag, or other fashion                item).    ADVANTAGE - The composition, when used as reducing agents                in the preparation of metal nanoparticles from a                corresponding metal ion, exhibit activity greater                than would have been expected from the additive                reduction activity (when tested using a                2,2-diphenyl-1-picrylhydrazyl (DPPH) assay), and                suggesting a synergetic relationship between the                different plants being used in the composition. The                method produces metal nanoparticles with a much                lower environmental impact than known processes.                The composition has a much higher antioxidant                activity (effectiveness as a biological reducing                agent) and lower cost than extracts from single                plants, and having a synergistic relationship as                described above, much less material and energy                usage is required in order to reduce the metal ions                to metal nanoparticles. The metal nanoparticle, as                it uses biological reducing agents, enables the use                of less toxic and more environmentally friendly                reagents compared with current manufacturing                routes. The method minimizes waste production                throughout the process by including a recycle loop                around the crystallization in order to maximize                process conversion at the point where the metal                ions are introduced, and avoiding the discharge of                large amounts of metal ions into the environment,                where the addition of a recycle loop around the                antioxidant extraction unit reduces waste and                minimizes environmental impact. The nanoparticles                have a protective bio-layer which protects the                nanoparticles without requiring additional capping                agents to be added.    DETAILED DESCRIPTION - An INDEPENDENT CLAIM is included for a metal                nanoparticle obtained or obtainable by the method,                and provided with a coating biopolymer layer. JOHNSON ET AL., MICRO & NANO LETTERS,, vol.          15, no. 2, 2020, pages 110 - 113;            MOHAMMAD POURHASSAN-MOGHADDAM ET AL., MICRO & NANO          LETTERS, vol. 9, no. 5, 2014, pages 345 - 350	96353-0-0-0 K P; 856-0-0-0 K P; 70-0-0-0 K P; 116-0-0-0 K P; 140-0-0-0 K P; 90-0-0-0 K P; 113-0-0-0 K P; 95801-0-0-0 K P; 1463-0-0-0 K P; 1161-0-0-0 K P; 108695-0-0-0 K P; 615-0-0-0 K P; 110-0-0-0 K P; 946-0-0-0 K P; 2927-0-0-0 K P; 71-0-0-0 K P; 587-0-0-0 K P			R03080 K P; R05319 K P; R05099 K P; R03084 K P; R03247 K P; R03036 K P; R03035 K P; R14267 K P; R10714 K P; R19499 K P; R18753 K P; R03037 K P; R03167 K P; RABV32 K P; R11536 K P; R07585 K P; R03031 K P; R03034 K P		WO2016058096-A1;  US2017245494-A1;  US10433543-B2	Making biodegradable bioactive film product used            to e.g. promote plant growth comprises dispersing            polyhydroxyalkanoate isolated from bacterial culture in            surfactant solution, drying, mixing with e.g. organism,            extruding and winding	BARDOSH W;  MCKENZIE R;  MEKONNEN T;  MIAZGA-RODRIGUEZ M;  NERKAR M;  MCKENZIE R R;  NERKAR M G	TERRAVERDAE BIOWORKS INC (TERR-Non-standard);  TERRAVERDAE BIOWORKS INC (TERR-Non-standard)	2016238399	   NOVELTY - Manufacturing (m1) biodegradable bioactive                film product comprises: (a) isolating                polyhydroxyalkanoate from a bacterial culture; (b)                optionally bleaching the polyhydroxyalkanoate; (c)                dispersing the polyhydroxyalkanoate in a surfactant                solution to form a dispersion; (d) drying the                dispersion to obtain dried polyhydroxyalkanoate                particles; (e) mixing the polyhydroxyalkanoate with                at least one bioactive compound or organism,                nucleating agent filler, plasticizer and impact                modifier or fiber to form a mixture; (f) extruding                the mixture as a film; and (g) winding the film                onto a spool.    USE - The process is useful for manufacturing:                biodegradable bioactive film product, where the                product is used for propagating a plant, promoting                growth of a plant or tree and suppressing growth of                weeds, preserving silage, preventing microbial                growth on a surface and providing seeds with a                biodegradable bioactive polymer coating (all                claimed), suppressing the growth of insect, fungi,                or other pests, and controlling loss of nutrient                and water from the soil, as soil conditioner to                increase the organic content of soils and biogas                source for electrical power generation, as a fuel                for vehicles, cooking fuel or as a substrate for                the production of polyhydroxyalkanoates and/or                other high-value biochemicals through a closed-loop                recycling process and packaging material during                transportation, delivery vehicle for natural                biostimulants and biocides and tree tube liners to                protect trees during early stages of growth and                provide a physical barrier that resists herbivore                attack and blocks weed; and biodegradable bioactive                coatings. No biological data given.    ADVANTAGE - The process produces: biodegradable bioactive                film product that provides controlled release of                active compounds or live organisms, is merely be                ploughed into the soil at the end of season or                before the next planning season where they will                degrade and disintegrate, thus utilized as                components of soil and to remove the chance of                contamination, increases organic content of soils,                boosts the productivity of crops by at least                15-25%, avoids the significant expense and labor                associated with the removal and disposal of their                spent mulch films produced from non-biodegradable                plastics by simply plowing the spent mulch film                into the soil where it undergoes biodegradation,                improves resiliency of trees and crops during cold                weather conditions, and has 25-100% tensile strain,                20-25 MPa tensile strength, 200-500 MPa tensile                modulus, 50-100 g tear resistance, 100-200 g dart                impact, oxygen permeability of less than 1 cm3/m3                day (23 degrees C/85% relative humidity) and water                permeation rate of 1500 g/m2.d (38 degrees C and                90% relative humidity); and coatings having                improved anti-corrosion property.    DETAILED DESCRIPTION - INDEPENDENT CLAIMS are also included                for:    (1) the biodegradable bioactive film                comprising 60-75 mass/mass% polyhydroxyalkanoate,                0.01-0.05 mass/mass% bioactive compound or                organism, 0.2-1 mass/mass% nucleating agent, 10-40                mass/mass% plasticizer, 0.5-30 mass/mass% filler                and 10-40 mass/mass% impact modifier or                fiber;    (2) propagating a plant, comprising forming a                wound on the plant and covering the wound with the                bioactive and biodegradable film, where the                bioactive compound comprises a plant growth hormone                promoting the generation of shoots or roots;    (3) promoting growth of a tree or plant,                comprising covering the plants with the bioactive                and biodegradable film, where the film includes a                filler that conducts electricity, and providing an                electric current to the film, to promote the                release of the bioactive compound or                organism;    (4) providing (m2) seeds with a biodegradable                bioactive polymer coating, comprising steps (a)-(d)                as above per se, (e) mixing the dried                polyhydroxyalkanoate particles with an organic                solvent and at least one additive to solubilize the                polyhydroxyalkanoate polymer in a mixture, (f)                soaking the seeds in the mixture or spray-coating                the seeds with the mixture, (g) drying the seeds to                obtain dried coated seeds and (h) applying a                bioactive compound or organism to the dried coated                seeds; and    (5) providing (m3) seeds with a biodegradable                bioactive polymer coating comprising isolating                polyhydroxyalkanoate from a bacterial culture,                optionally bleaching the polyhydroxyalkanoate,                dispersing the polyhydroxyalkanoate in a surfactant                solution to form a dispersion, drying the                dispersion to obtain dried polyhydroxyalkanoate                particles, preparing a triblock copolymer with the                dried polyhydroxyalkanoate particles, mixing the                triblock copolymer with an alpha -cyclodextrin to                obtain a hydrogel, mixing the hydrogel with a                bioactive compound or organism and applying the                hydrogel to the seeds. ET          AL.: "Microbial Polymers as a Degradable Carrier for          Pesticide Delivery", APPLIED BIOCHEMISTRY AND          MICROBIOLOGY, vol. 45, 2009, pages 384 - 388,          XP055274267,relevantClaims[1-14, 16-28, 30-32]	2211-0-0-2 K M; 2211-0-0-0 K M; 1013849-0-0-0 K M; 490-0-0-0 K M; 23902-0-0-0 K M; 129433-0-0-0 K M; 107456-1-0-0 K M; 949-1-0-0 K M; 129460-0-0-0 K M; 90356-0-0-0 K M; 107779-0-0-0 K M; 90688-1-0-0 K M; 151671-0-0-0 K M; 104427-0-0-0 K M; 99417-0-0-0 K M; 129411-0-0-0 ; 135402-0-0-0 ; 104420-0-0-0 ; 192393-0-0-0 ; 2211-0-0-3 ; 129417-0-0-0 ; 311-0-0-0 ; 89827-0-0-0 ; 107016-0-0-0 ; 129788-0-0-0 ; 686-0-0-0 ; 259-0-0-0 ; 20-0-0-0 ; 27-0-0-0 ; 23-0-0-0 ; 1-0-0-0 ; 209-0-0-0 ;  ; 7447-0-0-0 ; 1013-0-0-0 ; 135413-0-0-0 ; 444-0-0-0 ; 1013849-0-0-0 CL USE			R01778 K M; R01669 K M; R05085 K M; R90346 K M; R00113 K M; R00744 K M; R00746 K M; R00032 K M; R00290 K M; R07423 K M; R01148 K M; R01852 K M; R01863 K M; R03233 K M; RA02NV K M; RA01KR K M; R01868 K M; R00806 ; R24032 ; R24028 ; R24090 ; R05086 ; R01893 ; R01333 ; R01278 ; R01694 ; R01949 ; R01966 ; R00994 ; R00273 ; R00345 ; R00278 ; R00247 ; R01732 ; R01541 ; R00009 ; R00326 ; R24073 ; R00351 	1669-S; 0113-S; 0744-S; 0746-S; 0032-S; 0290-S; 1148-S; 1852-S; 1863-S; 1868-S	WO9944707-A2;  AU9929761-A;  BR9908464-A;  EP1059975-A2;  CN1292023-A;  US6284904-B1;  KR2001041516-A;  JP2002505310-W;  WO9944707-A3;  EP1059975-A4	Recovery of carboxylic acids, e.g. succinic acid, from carboxylic acid-containing solutions e.g. fermentation broths, is cost effective, versatile for variety of carboxylic acids e.g. amino acids	PONNAMPALAM E	MICHIGAN BIOTECHNOLOGY INST (MICH-Non-standard);  MICHIGAN BIOTECHNOLOGY INST (MICH-Non-standard)	1999550993	   NOVELTY - A method for recovering carboxylic acid from carboxylic acid-containing solutions, is new.    USE - The method is useful for recovering carboxylic acid from carboxylic acid-containing solutions including fermentation broths, biomass hydrolysates, dilute solutions of salt form of corresponding carboxylate anion or waste streams (claimed) including succinic acid, which is used as an intermediates in the synthesis of intermediates and specialty chemicals for the consumer product industries, as commodity chemical to replace for many of the benzene class of commodity and intermediate petrochemicals, as a food additive, plant-growth stimulator, intermediate in the manufacture of pharmaceuticals, and polymers and resins for lacquers, dyes and perfumes, as well as acetic acid, citric acid and lactic acid. Also used to produce corresponding esters in pure form. The methods are also used to recover carboxylic acids from fermentation reactions in which the carboxylic acid is produced as a secondary by-product, i.e. succinate produced during ethanol production by fermentation of corn, or as the primary product of the fermentation reaction, i.e. production of particular carboxylic acids by microorganisms.    ADVANTAGE - The method is cost effective, versatile for use with wide variety of different carboxylic acids including amino acids. Allows recovery of pure succinic acid crystals from fermentation broth at considerable cost savings because it employs fewer major unit operations than the prior art. Resin may be recycled. Non-ionic impurities are removed during the process.    DETAILED DESCRIPTION - The method comprises:    (a) contacting solution with anionic exchange resin;    (b) washing resin under conditions to remove materials other than carboxylate anions;    (c) displacing carboxylate anion from resin as carboxylic acid by washing resin with acid form of inorganic anion or anion stronger than carboxylate anion in amount effective to displace carboxylate anion the corresponding carboxylic acid; and    (d) collecting fractions containing carboxylic acid.    An INDEPENDENT CLAIM is also included for a method of producing an ester from a carboxylic acid-containing solution comprising:    (a) contacting solution with anionic exchange resin;    (b) washing resin under conditions to remove materials other than carboxylate anions;    (c) displacing carboxylate anion from resin as carboxylic acid by washing resin with an alcohol comprising the acid form of inorganic anion or anion stronger than carboxylate anion in amount effective to displace the carboxylic acid; and    (d) collecting fractions containing carboxylic acid. R00419 K P; R07029 K P; R00247 K P; R07345 K P	0900-P U; 0009-P U; 0419-P U; 0247-P U	US2012312478-A1;  US9233502-B2	Hot air manifold for heating and activating e.g.            polyurethane dispersion adhesive to seal e.g. woven            polypropylene bag used to pack dry food for dog, has            inlet duct joined to bottom, end or side walls to            provide air flow path into manifold	SARGIN G F;  JANSEN M E	COATING EXCELLENCE INT LLC (COAT-Non-standard)	2012R15963	   NOVELTY - The manifold has a top wall joined to a side                wall at approximately 90 degree angle and a back                wall. A bottom wall is joined to the side wall at                approximately at 90 degree angle. Another side wall                is joined to each of the top and bottom walls at                approximately 90 degree angle. Two end walls are                joined to the top wall, the side walls and the                bottom wall. An inlet duct is joined to the bottom                wall, the end wall or the side walls to provide an                air flow path from the inlet duct into the manifold                through openings in the side and top walls.    USE - Hot air manifold for heating and activating                adhesives e.g. polyurethane dispersion adhesive,                vinyl, acrylic, natural or synthetic rubber-based                adhesive, to seal a bag e.g. multi-wall paper bag                and woven polypropylene bag, which is utilized for                bulk packaging of food product such as dry food,                for pet such as dog and cat. Can also be used for                ground grains, seeds and chemical                fertilizers.    ADVANTAGE - The manifold is used for bags that are                fabricated entirely of a recyclable polypropylene                material with resin additives such as metallocene,                that is recyclable and is free of recycled or                contaminated polymers, so that the bag is reduced                in weight, high in resistance to abrasion, tearing                and puncture, and reusable, thus reducing waste of                the bags due to shipping costs and damaged bag                contents, and hence extending life of content in                the bag and reducing manufacturing cost of the bag                in an environment-friendly manner. The top wall is                recessed below a top edge margin to define a recess                along the top wall to space adhesive layers away                from the top wall and prevent contact between the                adhesive layers while the adhesive layers on a flap                portion and a bag section are heated to an adhesive                state by the hot air blown under pressure from a                hot air chamber.    DESCRIPTION OF DRAWING(S) - The drawing shows a partial perspective view                of a pinch closing and cooling apparatus of a hot                air sealer apparatus. A11-C01C;  A12-P02	B32B-037/06;  B29C-035/04;  B29C-053/36;  B29C-065/00;  B29C-065/10;  B29C-065/48;  B29C-065/50;  B29K-711/12;  B29L-031/00;  B31B-019/62;  B65B-051/18;  B65B-051/20;  B65B-007/08; USE - New disulfide-containing benzoxazine monomer                used for preparing polybenzoxazine derivative                vitrimer used as a reversible adhesive, sealant,                coating or encapsulating systems for substrates                selected from metal, polymer, glass and ceramic                material, or in three-dimensional (3D) printing                processes or in additive manufacturing processes                (all claimed).    ADVANTAGE - The vitrimers have self-healing, reshaping,                reprocessability and recycling properties. The                benzoxazine ring moiety gives thermosetting                properties such as high-temperature and                flammability performance, high strength, thermal                stability, low water absorption, chemical                resistance, low melt viscosities, and near-zero                shrinkage. Disulfide bonds and hydrogen bonds are                essential to form, in fine, polybenzoxazine                derivatives vitrimers having dynamic network that                allows the material to be recycled, reshaped and                reprocessed. A crystallization temperature (TSchalt-PCM) at which the phase change material exothermically changes from a fluid state to a crystalline state. The actuating element (1) between a first form in which the actuating element brings the nucleating agent into contact with the phase change material in order to trigger its crystallization, and a second form in which the actuating element brings the nucleation agent out of contact with the phase change material and can be reversibly switched back and forth. The two-way shape memory polymer of the actuator has a first switching temperature (TSchalt-1), in which it is transferred from its second form to the first form, and a second switching temperature higher than the first switching temperature, in which it is transferred from its first form to the second form.    USE - Latent heat storage device e.g. solar thermal systems for storing solar energy, for heat-storing underfloor and wall heating elements, for energy self-sufficient temperature control of transport and storage containers up to and including hand or handheld containers used for building.    ADVANTAGE - The simple and inexpensive trigger mechanism for a latent heat accumulator enables the crystallization of the supercooled melt of the phase change material to be initiated both in a reproducible and in an energy-self-sufficient manner. The actuating elements have a more complex structure than the actuating elements and greater strength and rigidity three dimensional printer is produced in one piece. The improved sealing effect is provided when the actuating element is in its second form. The improved sealing effect is ensured when the actuating element is in its second shape. The phase change material is provided with an antimicrobial finish in order to avoid undesired germ or fungus formation. The antimicrobial finish should be harmless to health to include fillers, fibers or threads based on silver and its sparingly or insoluble salts. The large amounts of phase change material are prevented from being released in the event of a leak in the reservoir. The two-way shape memory polymer of the actuating element is advantageously a plasticizable, thermoplastic polymer, which makes it easy to manufacture using virtually any thermoplastic processing method and, with regard to easy recycling, makes it more environmentally friendly than thermosets.    DETAILED DESCRIPTION - The melting temperature (TSchmelz-PCM) above the crystallization temperature, at which the phase change material changes from the crystalline state to the fluid state, and with at least one trigger mechanism for triggering the crystallization of the phase change material. The trigger mechanism comprises a crystallization nucleator which is in operative connection with a mechanical actuating element. The crystallization nucleation agent is applied to the surface of the actuating element and is dispersed into it and applied to the surface of a stationary or displaceable element. The crystallization nucleator is immobilized in a separate chamber (2) which is connected to and separated from the storage device receiving the phase change material by unit of the actuating element. The two-way shape memory polymer of the actuating element passive due to the ambient temperature and is actively brought to its first switching temperature (TSwitch-1). The storage device receiving the phase change material is assigned a heating device in order to heat the phase change material to a regeneration temperature (TReg-PCM) above its melting temperature for regeneration purposes. The two-way shape memory polymer of the actuating element has a first switching temperature at which it is converted from its second form into the first form, which lies between the melting temperature (TSmelt-PCM) and the crystallization temperature in the metastable supercooling range ( Delta TU-PCM) of the phase change material and has a second switching temperature which is higher than the first switching temperature, at which it is converted from its first form into the second form, which is below the regeneration temperature, below the melting temperature, but closer to the melting temperature than to the crystallization temperature of the phase change material. The phase change material contains the salt hydrate or is essentially entirely formed from it. The two-way shape memory polymer of the actuating element is the thermoplastic, polyester or polyether urethane elastomer. The two-way shape memory polymer of the actuating element contains the filler and reinforcement material, which from the group of substances absorbing electromagnetic radiation, based on of carbon, metals, metal oxides and metal clusters, magnetic and ferromagnetic substances, from the group of iron, iron oxide, nickel, zinc and their metal clusters, nanoclays, based on carbides, nitrides and oxides of silicon, zirconium and aluminum, and the reinforcing fiber is selected. The phase change material is mixed with the additive from the group of gel formers and is provided with an antimicrobial finish.    DESCRIPTION OF DRAWING(S) - The drawings show a graphical view of the temperature over time to illustrate the mode of operation of a latent heat accumulator with passive switching of the actuating element of its trigger mechanism made of two-way shape memory polymer purely on the basis of the ambient temperature, a graphical view of the temperature over time, essentially corresponding, to illustrate the mode of operation of a latent heat storage device with active switching of the actuating element of its triggering mechanism made of two-way shape memory polymer by unit of cooling the two-way shape memory polymer as required, a perspective view of the device that shows highly schematic views of an actuating element made of two-way shape memory polymer, in a first form, in which it brings a crystallization nucleator immobilized in a chamber into contact with a phase change material in order to crystallize to trigger the phase change material, on the other hand in a second form each at the top in which it closes the chamber receiving the nucleation agent in order to bring the nucleation agent out of contact with the phase change material.  GILLET J P;  GONZALEZ L J A;  JORDA E;  GILLET J;  G0NZALEZ LEON J A	CECA SA (CECA-C)	2009M65265	   NOVELTY - Composition comprises a surfactant (50-100 wt.%) comprising carboxyl substituted quaternary ammonium compound (I), a compound (0-15 wt.%) (A), carboxylic acid compound (0-40 wt.%) (B) and substituted quaternary ammonium compound (C).    USE - The composition or (I) is useful: as an adhesive dope in binders for road applications using anhydrous binders; and for the manufacture of bituminous products such as superficial coating, adhesive and impregnation layer, dense, semi-dense cold cast coating. The emulsion is useful for preparing a storable open coating, a grave emulsion, a cold dense coating, cold recycling or cold cast coating (all claimed).    ADVANTAGE - The composition has improved mechanical properties, cohesion property and tracking resistance.    DETAILED DESCRIPTION - Composition comprises a surfactant comprising carboxyl substituted quaternary ammonium compound of formula (R-CO-O-(CH2)2-N+(R1R2R3)X1-) (I) (50-100 wt.%), a compound (0-15 wt.%) of formula (HX1) (A), carboxylic acid compound (0-40 wt.%) of formula (R-CO-OH) (B) and hydroxyl substituted quaternary ammonium compound of formula (HO-(CH2)2-N+(R1R2R3)X1-) (C).    R = optionally hydroxylated 4-32C, preferably 7-21C hydrocarbon chain;    R1-R3 = 1-4C alkyl; and    X1 = halo or mesyl.    INDEPENDENT CLAIMS are included for:    (1) a bituminous emulsion comprising at least a bituminous binder and at least (I) or the composition;    (2) an anhydrous bituminous binder comprising a bituminous binder and (I) or the composition;    (3) a bituminous composition comprising at least a bituminous binder, (I) or the composition, at least a component capable of forming a supramolecular network, at least a supramolecular structure formed by assembling conventional polymers using physical bonds, where the polymers are grafted with at least one functional group by a group capable of interacting by hydrogen bond, and at least an additive comprising (i) a product of formula (R-O-((CH2CH(CH3)O)a-(CH2CH2O)b)cP(=O)-OHd), (ii) a product of reaction of (di)alk(en)ylphenols on 1-10C aldehydes, preferably paraformaldehyde or acetaldehyde, followed by (poly)oxyethylation and/or (poly)oxypropylation, 1-50C, preferably 3-12C alk(en)yl groups, where the part made by (poly)oxyethylation and/or (poly)oxypropylation has a molar mass of greater than or equal to 45 g/mol and less than 20000 g/mol and the number of phenolic units of product A is 3-50, (iii) (poly)oxyethylated and/or (poly)oxypropylated 2,2-bis(4-hydroxyphenyl) propane-epichlorohydrin copolymer, (iv) (poly)oxyethylated and/or (poly)oxypropylated bis(4-hydroxyphenyl) ethane-epichlorohydrin copolymer, (v) (poly)oxyethylated and/or (poly)oxypropylated bis(4-hydroxyphenyl) methane-epichlorohydrin copolymer, (vi) a product of (poly)oxyethylation and/or (poly)oxypropylation of alkyl dicarboxylic acid or its mixture, where the alkyl group is 1-20C, preferably 1-10C, where the parts made by (poly)oxyethylation and/or (poly)oxypropylation has a molar mass of greater than 100 g/mol and less than 20000 g/mol, (vii) a product of (poly)oxyethylation and/or (poly)oxypropylation of 10-30C fatty acid, preferably fatty acid of tall oil, (viii) a product of the reaction between the product (ii) and a mixture of the products (vi) and (vii), (ix) alk(en)yl(aryl) sulfonic acid salt and alk(en)yl(aryl)amine, where the alk(en)yl(aryl) units comprise 6-30C and preferably 1-70%; and    (4) a preparation of the bituminous composition comprising introducing surfactants, additives and components in a hot binder to all levels together or separately in the form of solid, liquid dispersed preferably with water in solution, in a bitumen tank, in-line injection in the bitumen and into the mixer containing aggregates, before, during or after- the addition of bitumen and spraying of the anhydrous binder.  JP5931061-B2;  EP2593494-A4;  KR1799132-B1;  EP2593494-B1;  CN103154078-B;  ES2671600-T3;  IN311490-B	Preparing extrusion-blow-moldable co-polyester            resin composition comprises charging in reactor at            least one pair of polyester-forming materials, and            subjecting reaction mixture to esterification,            ester-interchange reaction or glycolysation	KULKARNI S T;  SCHILLO S;  SOEKARNO A L;  VAN DER MEER H R;  VIJRA A;  VYAS C O;  ONKAR V C;  TAMMAJI K S;  VAN DER MEER R;  KULKAREUNI S T;  AKEUHILRESWI B;  BIYASEU C O;  ALBEREUTEU R S;  DEEO M R P;  JIMONE S;  VAN D M R	BASF SE (BADI-C);  PEARL ENG POLYMERS LTD (PEAR-Non-standard);  BASF SE (BADI-C);  PEARL ENG POLYMERS LTD (PEAR-Non-standard);  BASF SE (BADI-C);  BASF SE (BADI-C);  TAMMAJI K S (TAMM-Individual);  VIJRA A (VIJR-Individual);  ONKAR V C (ONKA-Individual);  SOEKARNO A L (SOEK-Individual);  VAN DER MEER R (VMEE-Individual);  SCHILLO S (SCHI-Individual)	2011B46085	   NOVELTY - Preparing an extrusion-blow-moldable                co-polyester resin composition comprises: (a)                charging in a reactor at least one pair of                polyester-forming materials; (b) subjecting the                reaction mixture to a method step selected from                esterification, ester-interchange reaction and                glycolysation yielding a pre-polymer; (c) charging                a chain extender selected from copolymers                containing at least two epoxy groups; (d)                subjecting the pre-polymer to polycondensation; (e)                crystallizing the amorphous chips; and (f)                processing the crystallized chips in a solid state                polymerizer.    USE - The method is useful for preparing                extrusion-blow-moldable co-polyester resin                composition, where the composition is useful for                preparing extrusion-blow-molded shaped article (all                claimed) for both food and non-food applications.                The composition can further be used in other                applications such as profile extrusions and for                manufacturing blown films which require high melt                strength polyester.    ADVANTAGE - The invention provides a gel-free PET                Polyester composition with high melt strength that                has high clarity, better color and gloss, improved                drawability and requisite impact strength. It is                also recyclable, and can be directly used by                existing EBM machines without need of any                additional process such as                blending/compounding.    DETAILED DESCRIPTION - Preparing an extrusion-blow-moldable                co-polyester resin composition comprises: (a)                charging in a reactor at least one pair of                polyester-forming materials selected from a                diol-dicarboxylic acid pair with a molar ratio of                about 1.04 to about 1.45, a diol-dicarboxylic ester                pair with a molar ratio of about 2 to about 2.25                and diol-recycled Polyethylene terephthalate (PET)                pair; a co-monomer, selected from isophthalic acid,                neopentyl glycol, pentaerythitol, glycerol, adipic                acid, 2,6 naphthalene dicarboxylate (NDC),                2,6-naphthalene dicarboxylic acid (NDA) and                dimethyl isophthalate, in the proportion of about 4                to about 20 wt.% with respect to the mass of the                reaction mixture; and at least one additive                selected from the group consisting of an impact                modifier, an antioxidant, a catalyst, an                acetaldehyde inhibitor and a color toner, to obtain                a reaction mixture; (b) subjecting the reaction                mixture to a method step selected from                esterification, ester-interchange reaction and                glycolysation yielding a pre-polymer; (c) charging                a chain extender selected from copolymers                containing at least two epoxy groups, in a                proportion of about 0.05 wt.% to about 2.0 wt.%,                preferably about 0.05 wt.% to about 0.8%, more                preferably 0.05 wt.% to 0.4 wt.% in the reaction                mixture during step (b) in at least one portion or                in continuous manner at controlled dosing rate when                the intrinsic viscosity of the reaction mixture is                more than 0.20, preferably more than 0.10; (d)                subjecting the pre-polymer to polycondensation at a                temperature in the range of about 270 degrees C to                about 305 degrees C under pressure of less than 10                mb, preferably below 2 mb, more preferably below 1                mb to obtain amorphous chips of I.V in range 0.40                to 0.80; (e) crystallizing the amorphous chips at a                temperature in the range of about 110 degrees C 170                degrees C to obtain chips with a crystallinity of                more than 30%; and (f) processing the crystallized                chips in a solid state polymerizer at a temperature                in the range of about 190 degrees C to about 225                degrees C until the required I.V of about 0.70 to                about 2.0, preferably about 0.90 to about 1.50,                more preferably about 0.90 to about 1.40 is                achieved to obtain an extrusion blow molding (EBM)                grade co-polyester resin composition. INDEPENDENT                CLAIMS are:    (1) an extrusion-blow-moldable co-polyester                resin composition with intrinsic viscosity in the                range of about 0.70 to about 2.0 which includes a                chain extender in the proportion of about 0.05% to                about 2.0% with respect to the mass of the resin,                added before polymerization in at least one portion                or in continuous manner at controlled dosing rate,                when the intrinsic viscosity of the reaction                mixture is less than 0.20, preferably less than                0.10; and    (2) an extrusion-blow-molded shaped article                optionally having an integral hollow handle formed                from the co-polyester resin composition, where the                shaped article is at least one article selected                from a parison, a container, a film and a tube;                with a volume in the range of about 20 ml to about                25 liters for food and nonfood applications.  ZA200800724-A;  IN200501898-I1;  US7820859-B2;  AU2005334674-B2;  CN101238090-B;  EP1910266-B1;  BR200520517-B1	Preparing highly pure L-(+)-lactic acid used as e.g. food additive involves esterifying crude acid in continuous counter current trickle phase mode to form methyl lactate; and reacting with reagent that converts volatiles to non-volatiles	BARVE P P;  KULKARNI B D;  NENE S N;  SHINDE R W;  GUPTE M Y;  JOSHI C N;  THITE G A;  CHAVAN V B;  DESHPANDE T R;  KULKARNI S S;  PHADNIS S H D;  TUSHAR R;  BARVE P;  KULKARNI B;  NENE S;  SHINDE R;  GUPTE M;  JOSHI C;  THITE G;  CHAVAN V;  DESHPANDE T	COUNCIL SCI&IND RES INDIA (COUI-C);  COUNCIL SCI&IND RES INDIA (COUI-C);  COUNCIL SCI & IND RES INDIA (COUI-C);  COUNCIL SCI&IND RES INDIA (COUI-C);  COUNCIL SCI&IND RES INDIA (COUI-C);  COUNCIL SCI&IND RES INDIA (COUI-C);  COUNCIL SCI&IND RES INDIA (COUI-C);  COUNCIL SCI & IND RES INDIA (COUI-C);  COUNCIL SCI & IND RES INDIA (COUI-C)	2007254591	   NOVELTY - Preparation of highly pure L-(+)-lactic acid involves: (a) esterifying crude dilute lactic acid solution in water using mineral acid and reacting with superheated methanol vapors in continuous counter current trickle phase mode (1) to obtain methyl lactate, removing continuously unreacted methanol and water rich layer separately as distillate and crude methyl lactate in continuous manner as overflow from reactor bottoms followed by recovery of reasonably pure methyl lactate; and (b) reacting methyl lactate with reagent capable of converting volatile components into non-volatile component.    USE - In the preparation of highly pure L-(+)-Lactic acid (claimed) useful in the production of dairy products, as an acidulating agent in alimentary field, as intermediate for the production of plasticizer agents, adhesives, pharmaceutical products, in the production of lactates; as mordant in wool dying; in the field of production of biocompatible and biodegradable polymers useful in the manufacturing bags, application films, in the field of sanitary field and medical applications; as food additive.    ADVANTAGE - The lactic acid obtained exhibits a purity of about 99.8 wt.% on water free basis and an optical purity of 99.9%. The L-(+)-lactic acid produced is odor and color free. The method provides L-(+)-lactic acid in high yield. The method is carried out at moderate condition thus avoiding formation of byproducts, impurities such as hydroxymethyl furfural and 2-pentene. The method can be conveniently operated at commercial scale. As the water associated with crude lactic acid and water of reaction is removed continuously by excess alcohol, the rate of formation of methyl lactate is very high thereby avoiding the need to maintain the still at higher temperature to achieve complete conversion of lactic acid. The method provides commercially viable process for the production of lactic acid from aqueous solution of crude lactic acid using continuous countercurrent-trickle phase manner.    DETAILED DESCRIPTION - Preparation of highly pure L-(+)-Lactic acid involves:    (a) esterifying crude dilute lactic acid solution in water using mineral acid by preheating the crude dilute lactic acid at a temperature of 105degreesC and reacting it with superheated methanol vapors maintained at 150degreesC in desired stoichiometric ratio, optionally in the presence of stabilizer, in continuous counter current trickle phase mode (1) to obtain the methyl lactate, removing continuously unreacted methanol and water rich layer separately as distillate and crude methyl lactate in a continuous manner as overflow from reactor bottoms followed by recovery of reasonably pure methyl lactate using evaporator with lactic acid to methyl lactate conversion of about 98.5% with no other byproduct formation;    (b) reacting the reasonably pure methyl lactate having purity of 93 - 95 wt.% with reagent capable of converting volatile components into non-volatile components, under reflux, for 1 hour, followed by distillation optionally with vacuum to obtain desired highly pure S-(-)-methyl lactate having purity of 99.8 wt.%, moisture of 0.03% and optical purity of (-)8.43degrees; and    (c) hydrolyzing the highly pure S-(-)-methyl lactate obtained in step (b) with distilled, metal contamination free or demineralized or de-ionized water, in the presence of highly pure L(+)-lactic acid as catalyst with a molar ratio of S-(-)-methyl lactate to catalyst of 10.8:1 - 3.4:1, at a temperature of 85 - 105degreesC, for 2 - 6 hours and allowing hydrolyzation of S-(-)-methyl lactate to L-(+)-lactic acid with the removal of methanol obtained during hydrolysis reaction continuously under reflux, at controlled temperature and pressure to obtain the highly pure L-(+)-lactic acid followed by treating with pretreated activated carbon to obtain the highly pure L-(+)-lactic acid solution in water and concentrating it in an evaporator to desired strength having purity of 99 - 99.8% and optical purity of 99 - 99.9% on water free basis without any byproduct and continuously collecting the methanol in a reservoir for being used/recycled in step (a).    DESCRIPTION OF DRAWING(S) - The figure shows experimental setup used in the production of L-(+)-lactic acid.    trickle-phase reactive distillation section (1)    packed column section (2)    reboiler (3)    reactor (4)    tank (5)    feedstock tank. Rodriguez, et al, "A Selective Method for the Preparation of Aliphatic Methyl Esters in the Presence of Aromatic Carboxylic Acids", Tetrahedron Letters, Elsevier, Amsterdam, NL, Nov. 19, 1998, pp. 8563-8566, XP004140582, vol. 39, No. 47.EP1910266-B1  RODRIGUEZ A ET AL: "A Selective Method for the Preparation of Aliphatic Methyl Esters in the Presence of Aromatic Carboxylic Acids" TETRAHEDRON LETTERS, ELSEVIER, AMSTERDAM, NL, vol. 39, no. 47, 19 November 1998 (1998-11-19), pages 8563-8566, XP004140582 ISSN: 0040-4039	7447-1-0-0 C K P; 277-0-0-1 S U; 277-0-0-0 K S U V; 408-0-0-0 K S U V; 2406-0-0-0 K S U V; 107317-0-0-0 K S U V; 789-0-0-0 K S U V; 58-0-0-0 K S U V; 15-0-0-0 K S; 7447-0-0-0 ; 7-0-0-0 			R10629 C K P; R00123 K U V; R01131 K U V; R14150 K U V; R00929 K U V; R14151 K U V; R01151 K U V; R01173 K U V; R01041 K U V; R00270 K S; R00009 ; R01714 	0123-S U; 1131-S U; 0929-S U; 1151-S U; 1173-S U; 1041-S U; 0270-S	DE102021106947-A1;  US2021300161-A1;  CN113459778-A	Carrier for carrier module of door assembly in            motor vehicle, has structure provided with opposite            sides bounded by outer perimeter, configured for            attachment to inner panel to close off opening, and            structure formed from non-synthetic material	FORTIN R E	MAGNA CLOSURES INC (MGIN-C);  MAGNA CLOSURES INC (MGIN-C);  MAGNA CLOSURES SPA (MGIN-C)	2021B27248	   NOVELTY - The carrier has an inner panel and an outer                panel (16) which define a door panel structure. The                inner panel has an opening to an inner door cavity                between the inner and outer panels. A structure is                provided with opposite sides bounded by an outer                perimeter, configured for attachment to the inner                panel to close off the opening. The structure is                formed from a non-synthetic material. The structure                comprises a layer of non-synthetic material. The                layer of non-synthetic material is coated with a                thermosetting resin. The thermosetting resin                comprises a non-synthetic binder material. The                layer includes a mesh layer of non-synthetic                material.    USE - Carrier for carrier module of door assembly in                motor vehicle e.g. car (from drawings).    ADVANTAGE - The carrier is easily recyclable and is                separated from non-recyclable materials through                optical recycling sorting cameras. The connecting                structure of the net enables individual filaments                to shift within the net and to move relative to one                another to prevent internal stresses from building                up within structure, so that the overstressing of                structure and fraying of mesh are prevented. The                fibers of the mesh are self-adjusting relative to                one another to prevent the build-up of internal                stresses within the structure, so that the ability                to shape the carrier is enhanced into the desired                shape and the tendency to the occurrence of cracks                within the structure during use and during an                accident is reduced. The different portions with                different densities and mechanical properties are                optimized in order to achieve weight targets and                the desired noise behavior. The material provides                the barrier with a structure that is light in                weight and low in cost, provides sound insulation                properties, offers high energy adsorption                properties in the event of a side impact, and has                some flame retardancy properties when an additive                is added to the polymer to achieve flame                retardancy. The net is flexible to allow bending,                expansion and compression of the structure as can                occur in the event of an impact. The net serving to                hold the structure together as a single portion of                material and prevent the structure breaks and a                portion or portions break off. The flexibility,                expansion and contraction of the tissue facilitate                the construction of the structure by preventing                internal stresses from building up within the                structure during construction. The beam assembly is                given a greatly increased tensile strength across                its width to increase the side impact strength of                the door assembly and the penetration of objects                and the inner lining in the interior of the motor                vehicle during a side impact to minimize. The                carrier for a carrier module of a door assembly of                a motor vehicle is environmentally friendly,                environmentally friendly, easily recyclable and can                be separated from non-recyclable materials through                optical recycling sorting cameras, has high                structural strength to provide the desired side                impact strength, is resistant to the ingress of                moisture and liquid, so that a desired barrier                function is provided to prevent the transfer of                moisture/liquid from a wet side of the carrier                module to prevent a dry side of the carrier module,                is resistant to decomposition in the presence of                moisture/liquid and reduces the weight of the                carrier module compared to those made of metal or                plastic, so that the fuel economy of the vehicle is                improved. The carrier is maintained as a single,                monolithic portion of material to avoid risk to                minimize damage to adjacent components and to                prevent separate portions from protruding from an                interior door cavity of a vehicle door panel                structure. The mesh prevents the structure from                breaking into individual portions of material in                the event of impact forces, so that the risk of                damage to adjacent components of the structure is                minimized and the individual portions are prevented                from protruding from an interior door cavity of a                vehicle door panel structure. The structure                internal stresses within the wearer's structure are                minimized both during manufacture, making it easier                to shape the structure as desired, and during the                occurrence of an impact force during an impact                condition, so that tearing the structure is                reduced.    DETAILED DESCRIPTION - An INDEPENDENT CLAIM is included for a method                of manufacturing a carrier for a carrier module of                a motor vehicle door assembly.    DESCRIPTION OF DRAWING(S) - The drawing shows a side view of the motor                vehicle with a door assembly constructed.    Door assembly (10)    Rear passenger door assembly (11)    Vehicle structure (12)    Outer panel (16)    Window (34) 			A95 (Transport - including vehicle parts, tyres and armaments.);  P73 (Layered products (B32).);  Q17 (Vehicle construction, fittings, propulsion arrangements (B60J-K, B60R, B60V-W))	A12-R02A;  A12-T04D;  P73-A02;  Q17-A06	B32B-005/22;  B60J-005/00;  B32B-027/12;  B32B-027/32;  B32B-005/02;  B60J-005/04	DE102021106947-A1   30 Sep 2021   B60J-005/00   202181Pages: 32   German;  US2021300161-A1   30 Sep 2021   B60J-005/04   202182   English;  CN113459778-A   01 Oct 2021   B60J-005/04   202185   Chinese	DE102021106947-A1    DE10106947    22 Mar 2021;   US2021300161-A1    US216791    30 Mar 2021;   CN113459778-A    CN10332849    29 Mar 2021	US2021300161-A1 Provisional Application US090939P;   US2021300161-A1 Provisional Application US003072P	US003072P    31 Mar 2020;  US090939P    13 Oct 2020;  US216791    30 Mar 2021					1145-0-0-0 			R00964 		DE10233179-A1	New N-vinylorganyl-perylene-3,4:9,10-tetracarbobisimide dyes and (co)polymers are used e.g. as dye or fluorescent dye, for bulk coloration of polymer or coloring natural material or in coating, ink, material test or semiconductor device	LANGHALS H;  WETZEL F	LANGHALS H (LANG-Individual)	2004228359	   NOVELTY - N-(Vinyl-(hetero)alkyl, -(hetero)alkenyl, -(hetero)alkynyl and -(hetero)aryl)-perylene-3,4:9,10-tetracarbobisimide dyes (I), with a range of possible N- and N'-substituents, are new.    USE - Dyes (I) and their (co)polymers are used as dyes and fluorescent dyes, for bulk coloration of polymers, e.g. polyvinyl chloride, cellulose acetate, polycarbonates, polyamides, polyurethanes, polyimides, polybenzimidazoles, melamine resins, silicones, polyesters, polyethers, polystyrene, polymethyl methacrylate, polyethylene, polypropylene, polyvinyl acetate, polyacrylonitrile, polybutadiene, polychlorobutadiene, polyisoprene and copolymers of these monomers; as vat dyes or mordant dyes (preferably with aluminum, chromium and iron salts as mordant) for coloring e.g. natural materials, e.g. paper, wood, straw, leather, skins or natural fibers, e.g. cotton, wool, silk, jute, sisal, hemp, linen or animal hair (e.g. horsehair) and conversion products, e.g. viscose, nitrate or cuprammonium rayon fibers; as colorant or pigment for coloring paints, lacquers, paper and printing colors, inks and other colors for painting and writing; as pigment in electrophotography e.g. for dry copying systems (Xerox RTM process) and laser printers (non-impact printing); for security marking. in which the great chemical and photochemical stability and optionally fluorescence of the substances are important, e.g. for marking checks, check cards, banknotes, documents, identity papers etc. to give a special unmistakable color; as additive for other colorants to produce a particular nuance, preferably a luminous tone; for marking objects for machine recognition by fluorescence, preferably for machine sorting and e.g. for recycling plastics; as fluorescent dye for machine-readable markings, preferably alpha-numeric prints or barcodes; for frequency conversion of light, e.g. to convert short-wave light to long-wave visible light; in display elements for various display, direction and marking purposes, e.g. passive displays and information and traffic signs, such as ampoules; in ink-jet printers, preferably in homogeneous solution as fluorescent ink; as starting material for organic superconductors; for solid fluorescent marking; for decorative and artistic purposes; for tracer purposes, e.g. in biochemistry, medicine, technology and natural science, in which the dyes can be bonded to the substrate covalently or by secondary valencies, e.g. hydrogen bridges or hydrophobic interactions (adsorption); as fluorescent dyes in highly sensitive detection process (see C. Aubert, J. Fuenfschilling, I. Zschikke-Graenacher and H. Langhals, Z. Analyt. Chem. 1985, 320, 361) or scintillators; as dyes or fluorescent dyes in optical light collector systems, fluorescent solar collectors (see H. Langhals, Nachr. Chem. Tech. Lab. 1980, 28, 716), displays activated by fluorescence (see W. Greubel and G. Baur, Elektronik 1977, 26, 6), in cold light sources for light-induced polymerization for making plastics; as dyes or fluorescent dyes for material test, e.g. in semiconductor circuit manufacture, for investigating microstructures of integrated semiconductor devices, in photoconductors, in photographic processes and in display, lighting or image conversion systems, stimulated by electrons, ions or UV radiation, e.g. in fluorescent displays, cathode ray tubes or phosphor tubes; as dyes or fluorescent dyes as part of integrated semiconductor circuit, either as such or with other semiconductors, e.g. in form of epitaxy; in chemiluminescent systems, e.g. chemiluminescent lighting rods, luminescent immuno-assay or other luminescent detection processes; as fluorescent marker, preferably for highlighting written characters or other graphic products and marking labels etc. to give particular optical color impression; as dyes or fluorescent dyes in dye lasers, preferably for producing laser rays; as dyes in dye lasers as Q-switch; as active substances for nonlinear optics, e.g. frequency doubling and tripling of laser light; and as rheology improvers (all claimed).    ADVANTAGE - Perylene dyes (perylene-3,4:9,10-tetracarbobisimides) are very fast to light and chemically stable and give fluorescence quantum yields up to 100%. They are also resistant to free radical polymerization conditions but are not polymerizable under usual conditions and can be dissolved from polymers e.g. in toluene. In contrast dyes (I) with e.g. a 4-vinylphenyl group on one imide nitrogen atom can be (co)polymerized to a polymer with depth of color and strength of surface fluorescence varying with the (I) content. They give high (100 %) quantum yields and are very fast to light, e.g. color and fluorescence unchanged after weeks in direct sunlight.    DETAILED DESCRIPTION - N-(Vinyl-(hetero)alkyl, -(hetero)alkenyl, -(hetero)alkynyl and -(hetero)aryl)-perylene-3,4:9,10-tetracarbobisimide dyes of formula (I) are new.    X = linear chain of 1-18 CH2 groups, in which (i) 1-6 CH2 may be replaced by A and (ii) up to 12 H atoms may be replaced by B or free valencies of methin groups or quaternary C atoms can be combined to form rings, e.g. cyclohexane rings;    A = CO, O, S, Se, Te, -CH=CH-, -CH=N-, an acetylenic group, phenylene, pyridindiylthiophendiyl or naphthylene or anthracendiyl (in which 1 or 2 CH groups may be replaced by N);    B = halogen, CN or 1-18 C linear alkyl, in which (i) 1-6 CH2 may be replaced by A and (ii) up to 12 H atoms may be replaced by B; and    R1, R2 = H or substituents.    The full definitions are given in the DEFINITIONS (Full Definitions) Field.    INDEPENDENT CLAIMS are also included for the following:    (1) homopolymers of (I);    (2) binary copolymers of (I) and a second component, e.g. styrene, butadiene, acrylonitrile, acrylamide, (meth)acrylic acid or esters, e.g. methyl, ethyl or 2-hydroxyethyl (meth)acrylate, vinyl esters, e.g. vinyl acetate, propionate or butyrate, vinyl chloride and vinylidene chloride, prepared by free radical polymerization using typical initiators e.g. azobisisobutyronitrile or dibenzoyl peroxide, anionic or cationic polymerization or polymerization using metal complexes;    (3) ternary and higher copolymers with 3-10 components, e.g. those listed above and also divinylbenzene as crosslinker, prepared as above;    (4) preparation of aromatic vinyl monomers, preferably (I), by decarboxylation of the corresponding cinnamic acid derivatives, preferably at 100-200 degrees C;    (5) synthesis of (I) from perylene anhydride imides and amines.    DESCRIPTION OF DRAWING(S) - The drawing shows the UV/visible absorption spectra (quantum yield 100%) of copolymers of N-(1-Hexyl-heptyl)-N'-(4-vinylphenyl)-perylene-3,4:9,10-bis(dicarboximide) and styrene in various ratios.  GILLET J P;  GONZALEZ L J A;  JORDA E;  GILLET J;  G0NZALEZ LEON J A;  GONZALEZ LEON J A	CECA SA (CECA-C);  CECA SA (CECA-C);  EIFFAGE TRAVAUX PUBLICS (EIFF-Non-standard);  EIFFAGE TRAVAUX PUBLICS (EIFF-Non-standard);  EIFFAGE TRAVAUX PUBLICS (EIFF-Non-standard)	2009M65264	   NOVELTY - Composition comprises a surfactant (50-100 wt.%) comprising carboxyl substituted quaternary ammonium compound (I), a compound (0-15 wt.%) (A), carboxylic acid compound (0-40 wt.%) (B) and substituted quaternary ammonium compound (C).    USE - The composition or (I) is useful: as an adhesive dope in binders for road applications using anhydrous binders; and for the manufacture of bituminous products such as superficial coating, adhesive and impregnation layer, dense, semi-dense cold cast coating. The emulsion is useful for preparing a storable open coating, a grave emulsion, a cold dense coating, cold recycling or cold cast coating (all claimed).    ADVANTAGE - The composition has improved mechanical properties, cohesion property and tracking resistance.    DETAILED DESCRIPTION - Composition comprises a surfactant comprising carboxyl substituted quaternary ammonium compound of formula (R-CO-O-(CH2)2-N+(R1R2R3)X1-) (I) (50-100 wt.%), a compound (0-15 wt.%) of formula (HX1) (A), carboxylic acid compound (0-40 wt.%) of formula (R-CO-OH) (B) and hydroxyl substituted quaternary ammonium compound of formula (HO-(CH2)2-N+(R1R2R3)X1-) (C).    R = optionally hydroxylated 4-32C, preferably 7-21C hydrocarbon chain;    R1-R3 = 1-4C alkyl; and    X1 = halo or mesyl.    INDEPENDENT CLAIMS are included for:    (1) a bituminous emulsion comprising at least a bituminous binder and at least (I) or the composition;    (2) an anhydrous bituminous binder comprising a bituminous binder and (I) or the composition;    (3) a bituminous composition comprising at least a bituminous binder, (I) or the composition, at least a component capable of forming a supramolecular network, at least a supramolecular structure formed by assembling conventional polymers using physical bonds, where the polymers are grafted with at least one functional group by a group capable of interacting by hydrogen bond, and at least an additive comprising (i) a product of formula (R-O-((CH2CH(CH3)O)a-(CH2CH2O)b)cP(=O)-OHd), (ii) a product of reaction of (di)alk(en)ylphenols on 1-10C aldehydes, preferably paraformaldehyde or acetaldehyde, followed by (poly)oxyethylation and/or (poly)oxypropylation, 1-50C, preferably 3-12C alk(en)yl groups, where the part made by (poly)oxyethylation and/or (poly)oxypropylation has a molar mass of \- 45 g/mol and less than 20000 g/mol and the number of phenolic units of product A is 3-50, (iii) (poly)oxyethylated and/or (poly)oxypropylated 2,2-bis(4-hydroxyphenyl) propane-epichlorohydrin copolymer, (iv) (poly)oxyethylated and/or (poly)oxypropylated bis(4-hydroxyphenyl) ethane-epichlorohydrin copolymer, (v) (poly)oxyethylated and/or (poly)oxypropylated bis(4-hydroxyphenyl) methane-epichlorohydrin copolymer, (vi) a product of (poly)oxyethylation and/or (poly)oxypropylation of alkyl dicarboxylic acid or its mixture, where the alkyl group is 1-20C, preferably 1-10C, where the parts made by (poly)oxyethylation and/or (poly)oxypropylation has a molar mass of greater than 100 g/mol and less than 20000 g/mol, (vii) a product of (poly)oxyethylation and/or (poly)oxypropylation of 10-30C fatty acid, preferably fatty acid of tall oil, (viii) a product of the reaction between the product (ii) and a mixture of the products (vi) and (vii), (ix) alk(en)yl(aryl) sulfonic acid salt and alk(en)yl(aryl)amine, where the alk(en)yl(aryl) units comprise 6-30C and preferably dodecylbenzene sulfonic acid salt and tallow amine, and also dodecylbenzene sulfonic acid salt and cyclohexylamine, (x) alk(en)yl(aryl) sulfonic acid salt and morpholine, pyrazine, pyrazoline, pyrazolone, pyridine, pyridone, pyrimidine, pyrrolidone, pyrroline, toluidine, imidazole, indole, indoline, oxindole, where the alk(en)yl(aryl) units comprise 6-30C and preferably dodecylbenzene sulfonic acid salt and morpholine, and (xi) statistical or block ethylene oxide-propylene oxide copolymers having a molar mass of 500-20000 g/mol, where the mass ratio of (ethylene oxide copolymer) is 1-70%;    (4) a preparation of (I) comprising reacting (B) with the reaction product of (C) (in which X1- is Cl-) and strong acid of (A);    (5) a use of choline triester type surfactant of formula (A1) (where a+b+c+d+e+f is 30) having 51C alkyl chain based on 54C trimer acid, choline triester type surfactant of formula (B1) (where a+b is 8) having 19C alkyl chain based on 22C carboxylic triacid, choline triester type surfactant of formula (C1) (where a+b+c+d is 20) having 34C alkyl chain based on 36C dimer acid, and choline triester type surfactant of formula (D1) (where a+b is 8) having 19C alkyl chain based on 21C carboxylic diacid, as an adhesive dope in binders for road applications using anhydrous binders; and    (6) a preparation of the bituminous composition comprising introducing surfactants, additives and components in a hot binder to all levels together or separately in the form of solid, liquid dispersed preferably with water in solution, in a bitumen tank, in-line injection in the bitumen and into the mixer containing aggregates, before, during or after- the addition of bitumen and spraying of the anhydrous binder.
